\section*{Three-Dimensional Visualization of the Gradients $\nabla \mathcal{K}$}

After simulating and visualizing the structure of the informational field $\mathcal{K}(x, y, z)$, it is essential to analyze the direction and intensity of the local informational gradient $\vec{\nabla \mathcal{K}}$, which governs the propagation of coherence within the Telascura.

In this section, we represent the three-dimensional vector field $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ using directional arrows (3D quiver plot), highlighting regions of high informational flow, stationary points, and possible nodal coupling configurations.

\subsection*{Simulation Method}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Construction of the informational field $\mathcal{K}(x,y,z)$ as a coherent initial configuration (Gaussian wave or centered random fluctuation).
  \item Computation of the three-dimensional numerical gradient $(\partial_x \mathcal{K}, \partial_y \mathcal{K}, \partial_z \mathcal{K})$ using \texttt{numpy.gradient}.
  \item Normalization of the vectors for directional representation.
  \item Visualization of three-dimensional arrows on a sampled grid using \texttt{matplotlib} with \texttt{ax.quiver}.
\end{itemize}
\newpage
\subsection*{Python Script – Vector Field $\nabla \mathcal{K}$}

\begin{lstlisting}[language=Python, caption={Visualization of gradients $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ on 3D field}, label={lst:codex_nablaK}]
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D

# Parameters
N = 20
x = y = z = np.linspace(-1, 1, N)
X, Y, Z = np.meshgrid(x, y, z, indexing='ij')

# Coherent initial field (informational bubble)
K = np.exp(-(X**2 + Y**2 + Z**2) * 10)

# Gradient calculation
dK_dx, dK_dy, dK_dz = np.gradient(K, x, y, z)

# Subsampling for graphical clarity
step = 3
Xq = X[::step, ::step, ::step]
Yq = Y[::step, ::step, ::step]
Zq = Z[::step, ::step, ::step]
U = dK_dx[::step, ::step, ::step]
V = dK_dy[::step, ::step, ::step]
W = dK_dz[::step, ::step, ::step]

# Visualization
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10, 8))
ax = fig.add_subplot(111, projection='3d')
ax.quiver(Xq, Yq, Zq, U, V, W, length=0.1, normalize=True, color='blue')
ax.set_title(r"Vector Field $\vec{\nabla \mathcal{K}}(x,y,z)$ – Codex Alpha")
ax.set_xlabel("x")
ax.set_ylabel("y")
ax.set_zlabel("z")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
\end{lstlisting}

\subsection*{Analysis and Interpretation}

\begin{itemize}
  \item The arrows represent the intensity and direction of the informational gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ at each point in the volume.
  \item Regions where vectors converge or diverge respectively indicate informational attractors and repulsors.
  \item This type of visualization is useful for:
    \begin{itemize}
      \item tracing coherent flows in complex informational nodes;
      \item identifying isocoherent surfaces at $\nabla \mathcal{K} \approx 0$;
      \item modeling couplings and interactions between domains in the Telascura.
    \end{itemize}
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Graphical Output}

\begin{figure}[H]
  \centering
  \includegraphics[width=0.9\textwidth]{gradienti_informazionali_3D_codex_alpha.png}

  \label{fig:nablaK_codex}
\end{figure}

The image shows the spatial distribution of the partial derivatives of the informational field $\mathcal{K}$ along the three Cartesian axes, generating a coherent vector field on a discrete scale. The vectors display the direction and intensity of informational flow near a simulated coherent node.

Regions with high densities of converging or diverging vectors can be interpreted as:
\begin{itemize}
  \item \textbf{Informational Attractors} $\left( \nabla \cdot \vec{\nabla \mathcal{K}} < 0 \right)$, where a local increase in informational coherence occurs;
  \item \textbf{Stationary Points} $\left( \vec{\nabla \mathcal{K}} \approx 0 \right)$, representing areas of equilibrium or nodal symmetry;

This representation is functional for mapping the emerging dynamics within the informational network $\mathcal{K}$ according to the coherence metric $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ of the Codex Alpha.

\subsection*{Automatic Generation of Entangled Nodes}

The model has been extended to the generation of multiple interconnected nodes $\mathcal{K}_i$ within the Telascura network. Each node is represented by a coherent informational distribution, centered in a specific domain $(x_i, y_i, z_i)$ and characterized by a local gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}_i$.

The overlay of multiple nodes generates an overall field:

\[
\mathcal{K}_{\text{tot}}(x,y,z) = \sum_{i} \mathcal{K}_i(x,y,z)
\quad \Rightarrow \quad
\vec{\nabla \mathcal{K}}_{\text{tot}} = \nabla \left( \sum_{i} \mathcal{K}_i \right)
\]

This structure reproduces the effect of an **entangled informational node**, where the spatial derivatives of $\mathcal{K}_i$ overlap coherently, generating:

\begin{itemize}
  \item \textbf{Coherent Bridges} between distinct spatial regions;
  \item \textbf{Informational Threads} with low divergence between nodes;
  \item \textbf{Simulation of topological entanglement} within the Telascura.
\end{itemize}

The following model simulates the formation of an **entangled informational domain** within the Telascura, obtained by **coherent superposition** of multiple 3D Gaussian nodes. Each node represents a localized distribution of the informational field $\mathcal{K}_i$, centered at a specific location and with defined amplitude and width.

The composition produces a **coherent multipolar structure**, and the resulting gradient $\vec{\nabla \mathcal{K}_{\text{tot}}}$ is visualized through a three-dimensional vector field.

\begin{itemize}
  \item The primary nodes are placed at $\{-2,0,0\}$, $\{+2,0,0\}$ and $\{0,+2,0\}$;
  \item The informational overlay is obtained by summing the local fields $\mathcal{K}_i$;
  \item The global gradient is calculated via finite differences on a discrete grid;
  \item The visualization adopts a \texttt{quiver3D} map to show the direction and intensity of the vectors $\vec{\nabla \mathcal{K}}$.
\end{itemize}
\newpage
\subsection*{Python Script}

\begin{lstlisting}[language=Python, caption={Script for automatic generation of entangled nodes and their 3D vector gradient}]
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D

# 3D Gaussian function centered at (x0, y0, z0)
def nodo_entangled(x, y, z, x0, y0, z0, amp=1, sigma=1):
    return amp * np.exp(-((x - x0)**2 + (y - y0)**2 + (z - z0)**2) / (2 * sigma**2))

# Spatial grid
x = y = z = np.linspace(-5, 5, 50)
X, Y, Z = np.meshgrid(x, y, z)

# Definition of three entangled informational nodes
K1 = nodo_entangled(X, Y, Z, -2, 0, 0, amp=1, sigma=1.2)
K2 = nodo_entangled(X, Y, Z, +2, 0, 0, amp=1, sigma=1.2)
K3 = nodo_entangled(X, Y, Z, 0, +2, 0, amp=1, sigma=1.2)

# Coherent informational overlay
K_total = K1 + K2 + K3

# Total gradient (vector field)
grad_Kx, grad_Ky, grad_Kz = np.gradient(K_total)

# 3D vector visualization of the entangled field
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10, 8))
ax = fig.add_subplot(111, projection='3d')
skip = (slice(None, None, 4),) * 3

ax.quiver(X[skip], Y[skip], Z[skip],
          grad_Kx[skip], grad_Ky[skip], grad_Kz[skip],
          length=0.6, normalize=True, color='purple', linewidth=0.5)

ax.set_title("Entangled Vector Fields $\nabla \mathcal{K}_i$")
ax.set_xlabel("X")
ax.set_ylabel("Y")
ax.set_zlabel("Z")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
\end{lstlisting}

The figure shows the resulting three-dimensional vector field from three connected nodes.

\begin{figure}[H]
  \centering
  \includegraphics[width=0.9\textwidth]{gradienti_entangled_codex_alpha.png}
  \caption{Visualization of the vector field $\vec{\nabla \mathcal{K}}_{\text{tot}}$ generated by the coherent superposition of three Gaussian informational nodes. The convergence regions between arrows represent entangled channels between spatially separated domains but connected by informational coherence.}
  \label{fig:entangled_nodes}
\end{figure}

The graphic displays the three-dimensional distribution of the informational vector field $\vec{\nabla \mathcal{K}}_{\text{tot}}$, resulting from the coherent superposition of three Gaussian nodes located at distinct points in space.

Each node represents a region of **maximum informational coherence** within the Telascura, and their interaction produces a complex pattern of **vectorial entanglement**. The arrows indicate the direction and intensity of the local informational gradient, with higher density in convergence areas.

These configurations are fundamental for modeling the structure of **negative mass nodes** and simulating the interconnection between remote quantum domains via the field $\mathcal{K}$. The resulting $\vec{\nabla \mathcal{K}}_{\text{tot}}$ acts as a coherence vector capable of supporting quantum flows and distributed computational logics within the Telascura.

\subsection*{Integration of Real Data – From Measurement to Telascopic Coherence}

The computational infrastructure of Codex Alpha enables the transformation of real datasets – from astrophysical experiments, cosmological simulations, or local observations – into **simulable informational fields**, using standard formats like \texttt{.csv} and \texttt{.fits}.

In the bidimensional case, it is possible to load a scalar map $K_{\text{obs}}(x,y)$ obtained for instance from an observational distribution of pulsars or light intensity, interpolate it on a continuous grid, and compute its gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}_{\text{obs}}$. This gradient provides the local direction of maximum variation of information, useful for simulating coherence dynamics and modeling nodal flows.

\begin{itemize}
  \item The emerging structures can be superimposed onto simulated or existing nodes.
  \item The gradients $\nabla \mathcal{K}_{\text{obs}}$ can serve as input for evolutionary protocols and predictive models.
\end{itemize}

Such configurations represent the direct contact point between the observable and the coherent simulation in Telascopic space.
\newpage
\subsection*{Python Script} 

\begin{lstlisting}[language=Python, caption={Computation of the vector field $\vec{\nabla \mathcal{K}}$ from observational CSV map}, label={lst:gradK_csv}]
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from scipy.interpolate import griddata

# Load data from CSV file (columns: x, y, K)
data = pd.read_csv('dati_kappa.csv')  # <-- CSV file with columns: x, y, K

# Extract values
x = data['x'].values
y = data['y'].values
K = data['K'].values

# Create regular grid
xi = np.linspace(min(x), max(x), 100)
yi = np.linspace(min(y), max(y), 100)
Xi, Yi = np.meshgrid(xi, yi)

# Interpolation of scalar field K(x,y)
Ki = griddata((x, y), K, (Xi, Yi), method='cubic')

# Informational gradient calculation
grad_Kx, grad_Ky = np.gradient(Ki)

# Vector field visualization $\nabla \mathcal{K}$
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
plt.quiver(Xi, Yi, grad_Kx, grad_Ky, color='darkcyan')
plt.title("Field $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ derived from Observational Data (CSV)")
plt.xlabel("X")
plt.ylabel("Y")
plt.axis('equal')
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
\end{lstlisting}

\subsection*{Observational Integration via FITS Maps}

To expand the compatibility of the \texttt{Codex Alpha} model with real data, a pipeline has been implemented for the direct analysis of \texttt{.FITS} files (Flexible Image Transport System), the astrophysical standard for storing cosmological maps (e.g., Planck, HEALPix, Swift BAT, HEASARC).

The goal is to convert real observational data into simulable informational distributions, creating an operational bridge between observational cosmology and emergent dynamics within the Telascura.

\begin{itemize}
  \item $\mathcal{K}(x,y)$: field extracted from the FITS map (e.g., thermal intensity or radio signal);
  \item $\nabla \mathcal{K}(x,y)$: informational gradient, computed via numerical differentiation;
  \item Resulting vector field: represents observable or simulable coherence flows in the Telascura formalism.
\end{itemize}

\vspace{1em}
\noindent Below is a double example with two distinct Planck datasets: the \texttt{I\_STOKES} map and the HFI 143 GHz map.

\begin{lstlisting}[language=Python, caption={Processing the I\_STOKES component from Planck Commander FITS file}, label={lst:fits_planck}]
import numpy as np
from astropy.io import fits
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the FITS file (e.g., COM_CMB_IQU-commander_2048_R3.00_full.fits)
hdul = fits.open('COM_CMB_IQU-commander_2048_R3.00_full.fits')
cmb = hdul['I_STOKES'].data  # intensity map
hdul.close()

# Compute informational gradient
grad_y, grad_x = np.gradient(cmb)

# Vector field visualization $\nabla \mathcal{K}$
plt.figure(figsize=(8,6))
plt.quiver(grad_x, grad_y, color='navy', scale=5e-6)
plt.title("Field $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ extracted from CMB Planck map")
plt.xlabel("Pixel X")
plt.ylabel("Pixel Y")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
\end{lstlisting}

\begin{lstlisting}[language=Python, caption={Extracting field $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ from Planck HFI 143 GHz map}, label={lst:planck_real_example}]
import numpy as np

\section*{Simulation of Stationary Coherent Nodes}

This section describes three fundamental classes of stationary coherent informational nodes, each simulated under different assumptions of metric and matter coupling. The simulations are carried out using scalar fields $\mathcal{K}(x,y,z,t)$ with coherent distribution, stationary (or quasi-stationary) evolution, and a condition of maximum localized informational gradient.

\subsection*{Case A – Coherent Spherical Node in Minkowski Metric}

In the absence of gravitational curvature (flat spacetime), the coherent node assumes spherical symmetry and radial distribution of the informational field:

\[
\mathcal{K}(r,t) = \mathcal{K}_0 \, e^{-\alpha r^2} \cos(\omega t)
\]

\begin{itemize}
  \item Field centered at $r = 0$, stable Gaussian distribution.
  \item Maximum coherence at the center: $\nabla \mathcal{K}(0) \rightarrow 0$.
  \item No gravitational feedback: $\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu} \rightarrow 0$.
  \item Represents an ideal stationary node in flat quantum vacuum.
\end{itemize}

\vspace{1em}
\textbf{Visualization:} 3D rendering of the $\mathcal{K}$ distribution and the vector field $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ on a Cartesian grid.

\subsection*{Case B – Radially Deforming Node on Schwarzschild Background}

Classical gravitational curvature is introduced via the Schwarzschild metric:

\[
ds^2 = -\left(1 - \frac{2GM}{r}\right) dt^2 + \left(1 - \frac{2GM}{r}\right)^{-1} dr^2 + r^2 d\Omega^2
\]

The coherent node is deformed by curvature:

\[
\mathcal{K}(r) = \mathcal{K}_0 \, e^{-\beta(r - r_s)^2}
\]

where $r_s = 2GM$ is the Schwarzschild radius.

\begin{itemize}
  \item Gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ is maximal near the horizon.
  \item Emergence of asymmetric structures in the Telascura.
  \item Possible application as interface between negative mass and positive gravitational well.
\end{itemize}

\textbf{Note:} this simulation constitutes the first step toward Telascura–GR unification.

\vspace{1em}
\noindent
\textbf{Distinctive Codex Alpha Predictions for the Deformed Schwarzschild Node} \\
In the Telascura formalism, the Schwarzschild metric emerges only as a limiting solution for $\nabla \mathcal{K} \rightarrow 0$, corresponding to an absence or massive distribution of informational coherence. However, in the presence of a coherent node with radial symmetry, the gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ introduces an asymmetric informational deformation that breaks the perfect spherical symmetry of classical spacetime, while preserving the external Schwarzschildian appearance.

This deformation manifests in the tensor $\Delta_{\mu\nu}$ as **directional informational polarization**, visible in simulations as more intense gradients along privileged axes (typically radial). Such deformations generate:
\begin{itemize}
    \item a shift in the effective radius of the informational horizon;
    \item slight anisotropy in the propagation of $\mathcal{K}$ waves near the node;
    \item the presence of off-axis “coherence lobes”, absent in GR.
\end{itemize}

A unique prediction of Codex Alpha compared to General Relativity is thus the existence of **peripheral informational zones**, coherent but not gravitationally attractive, capable of influencing matter through variations in the gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}$, rather than through classical curvature $R_{\mu\nu}$.



\subsection*{Case C – Pulsating Node with Matter Coupling ($\lambda \neq 0$)}

A coupling term $\lambda$ is introduced between $\mathcal{K}$ and the matter density $\rho(x)$:

\[
\Box \mathcal{K} + \lambda \rho(x) \mathcal{K} = 0
\]

We simulate a pulsating coherent node in the presence of non-uniformly distributed matter.

\begin{itemize}
  \item Pulsation frequency modulated by local density: $\omega = \omega(\rho)$.
  \item Possible formation of coherent resonant or transient states.
  \item Emergence of macroscopic quantum effects (e.g., local retrocausality).
\end{itemize}

\textbf{Numerical simulation:} temporal evolution of the node in the presence of $\rho(x) = \rho_0 \sin^2(\pi x/L)$.

---

\noindent
These three cases define the basis of coherent informational morphology in spacetime and represent the starting grid for further extensions in subsequent chapters of Codex Alpha (e.g., nodal engine, retrotemporal fluctuations, entangled propagation).

\vspace{1em}
\noindent
\textbf{Physical Meaning of Modulated Nodal Pulsation} \\
In the pulsating case, where $\lambda \neq 0$ regulates the coupling between $\mathcal{K}$ and the local matter density $\rho(x)$, temporal fluctuations are observed in the maximum coherence value of the node. These fluctuations manifest as **periodic oscillations** whose frequency $\omega(x)$ is a direct function of the local value of $\rho(x)$, with an estimated dependence of the form:
\[
\omega(x) \sim \omega_0 \cdot \left(1 + \kappa \rho(x)\right)
\]
where $\kappa$ is a dimensional coupling parameter.

Physically, this implies that:
\begin{itemize}
    \item a node immersed in a dense matter field (e.g., interstellar gas) exhibits a higher pulsation frequency;
    \item an informational signature is generated, potentially observable as a **secondary modulation of gravitational signals**, similar to beating in resonant systems;
    \item in the presence of density gradients, interference patterns form in the $\mathcal{K}$ field, potentially associated with quantum field fluctuations or structured background noise.
\end{itemize}

These predictions offer a point of contact with potential observables, including modulated stochastic gravitational signals, interference on coherent cosmic background, or local decoherence effects in advanced interferometric experiments \cite{toros2023quantumgravity}.

\subsection*{Simulation of Stationary Coherent Nodes}

Three representative cases are presented below:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\textbf{\Alph*.}]
  \item \textbf{Coherent spherical node (Minkowski Metric)}: stationary Gaussian distribution.
  \item \textbf{Radially deforming Schwarzschild node}: the function $K(r)$ is modulated by classical curvature.
  \item \textbf{Pulsating node with matter}: temporal oscillations induced by $\lambda K_{\mathrm{matter}}$ coupling.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{figure}[H]
  \centering
  \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{nodi_stazionari_mink_schw_puls.png}
  \caption{From left to right: Case A (Minkowski), Case B (Schwarzschild), Case C (Pulsating Node). Surfaces in $(r,\theta/K)$ or $(r,t,K)$ coordinates visualize the spatial/temporal structure of the nodes.}
  \label{fig:nodi_stazionari}
\end{figure}

\subsubsection*{Python Code for Stationary Node Simulation}

\begin{lstlisting}[caption={Python script for graphical generation of the three nodes: Case A (Minkowski), Case B (Schwarzschild), Case C (Pulsating node with matter)}]
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D

# Radial grid
r = np.linspace(0, 10, 200)
R, T = np.meshgrid(r, np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 200))

# Case A: Gaussian node
A, sigma = 1.0, 2.0
K_A = A * np.exp(-R**2 / sigma**2)

# Case B: Schwarzschild node
M = 0.5
f = np.sqrt(1 - 2*M / (R + 1e-6))
K_B = A * f * np.exp(-R**2 / sigma**2)

# Case C: Pulsating node with matter
omega, lam = 3.0, 0.2
rho = np.exp(-R**2 / 16)
K_C = A * (1 + lam * rho) * np.exp(-R**2 / sigma**2) * np.sin(omega * T)

# Visualization
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(18,5))

ax = fig.add_subplot(131, projection='3d')
ax.plot_surface(R, T, K_A, cmap='viridis')
ax.set_title('Case A: Minkowski Node')

ax = fig.add_subplot(132, projection='3d')
ax.plot_surface(R, T, K_B, cmap='plasma')
ax.set_title('Case B: Schwarzschild Node')

ax = fig.add_subplot(133, projection='3d')
ax.plot_surface(R, T, K_C, cmap='inferno')
ax.set_title('Case C: Pulsating Node with Matter')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
\end{lstlisting}

\paragraph{Technical Note:} The Python code has been verified for consistency with the $\mathcal{K}$ informational model and produces visualizations compatible with the formal requirements of emergent dynamics $\nabla \mathcal{K}$.



\section*{Analysis of Simulation Outputs}

In this section, we quantitatively analyze the simulations presented in Section: Nodal Simulations, focusing on three fundamental aspects of informational dynamics in coherent nodes:

\begin{enumerate}
    \item the informational gradient map $\nabla \mathcal{K}$;
    \item the informational tensor $\Delta_{\mu\nu} = \partial_\mu \mathcal{K} \, \partial_\nu \mathcal{K}$;
    \item the measurement of local coherence and the identification of informational attractors.
\end{enumerate}

The tensor $\Delta_{\mu\nu}$ represents an informational generalization of the classical metric and is used in Codex Alpha as the basis for defining *spatial coherence* in Telascura nodes. Since $\Delta_{\mu\nu}$ is symmetric and semi-definite positive, it acts as a local informational metric for the coherent propagation of information. The measure $C(x,y)$ behaves as a normalized complement of the vector norm, allowing the identification of stationary nodes with maximum coherence.

\subsection*{Visualization of the $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ Map}

For each simulated node (Minkowski, Schwarzschild, Matter), we extracted the Cartesian map of the gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}(x,y)$. Regions where $\nabla \mathcal{K} \rightarrow 0$ are interpreted as coherent centers (local attractors), according to the formal definition in the chapter explaining the Telascura.

\begin{figure}[H]
    \centering
    \includegraphics[width=0.9\textwidth]{mappa_gradiente_K.png}
    \caption{Vector map of the field $\nabla \mathcal{K}(x,y)$ for a spherical node. Vectors converge toward the coherent center, identified as an informational attractor.}
    \label{fig:mappa_gradiente}
\end{figure}

\subsection*{Automatic Generation of the Informational Tensor $\Delta_{\mu\nu}$}

The three main components of the informational tensor were computed in the $(x,y)$ plane:

\begin{itemize}
    \item $\Delta_{xx} = (\partial_x \mathcal{K})^2$
    \item $\Delta_{xy} = \partial_x \mathcal{K} \cdot \partial_y \mathcal{K}$
    \item $\Delta_{yy} = (\partial_y \mathcal{K})^2$
\end{itemize}

\begin{figure}[H]
  \centering
  \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{tensore_K_components.png}
  \caption{Main components of the informational tensor $\Delta_{\mu\nu}(\nabla \mathcal{K})$ in the node region. From left: $\Delta_{xx}$, $\Delta_{xy}$, $\Delta_{yy}$. Bright regions indicate strong gradients and bifurcated structures.}
  \label{fig:delta_tensor}
\end{figure}

\subsection*{Measurement of Stationary Coherence and Identification of Attractors}

As defined in the chapter on computational formalism, local coherence is measured through the normalized gradient modulus:

\[
C(x,y) = 1 - \frac{|\nabla \mathcal{K}(x,y)|}{\max |\nabla \mathcal{K}|}
\]

Points where $C(x,y) \rightarrow 1$ are considered *coherent stationary nodes*, while rapid variations indicate informational bifurcations or instabilities.

\begin{figure}[H]
    \centering
    \includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{coerenza_nodale_mappa.png}
    \caption{Map of informational coherence $C(x,y)$. Maxima (yellow) represent stationary informational attractors.}
    \label{fig:coerenza_mappa}
\end{figure}

\subsection*{Python Script for Computational Analysis}

The following Python code, executed in a \texttt{Python 3.11} environment with \texttt{NumPy} and \texttt{Matplotlib}, was used to automatically generate the images shown in the previous figures.

\vspace{0.5em}
\noindent\textbf{1. Full Script for All Components:}

\begin{lstlisting}[language=Python, caption={Python Script for $\nabla \mathcal{K}$, $\Delta_{\mu\nu}$, and $C(x,y)$}]
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# 2D grid
x = np.linspace(-5, 5, 300)
y = np.linspace(-5, 5, 300)
X, Y = np.meshgrid(x, y)

# Stationary spherical node (Case A)
K = np.exp(- (X**2 + Y**2) / 4 )

# Partial derivatives
Kx, Ky = np.gradient(K, x[1] - x[0], y[1] - y[0])

# Informational tensor
D_xx = Kx**2
D_xy = Kx * Ky
D_yy = Ky**2

# Informational coherence map
grad_norm = np.sqrt(Kx**2 + Ky**2)
C = 1 - grad_norm / np.max(grad_norm)

# ------------------ GRADIENT PLOT ------------------
plt.figure(figsize=(6,5))
plt.quiver(X, Y, Kx, Ky)
plt.title("Vector field $\nabla \mathcal{K}(x,y)$")
plt.xlabel("x")
plt.ylabel("y")
plt.savefig("mappa_gradiente_K.png", dpi=300)
plt.close()

# ------------------ TENSOR PLOT ------------------
fig, axs = plt.subplots(1, 3, figsize=(15,4))
axs[0].imshow(D_xx, cmap='viridis', extent=[-5,5,-5,5])
axs[0].set_title("$\Delta_{xx}$")
axs[1].imshow(D_xy, cmap='coolwarm', extent=[-5,5,-5,5])
axs[1].set_title("$\Delta_{xy}$")
axs[2].imshow(D_yy, cmap='plasma', extent=[-5,5,-5,5])
axs[2].set_title("$\Delta_{yy}$")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("tensore_K_components.png", dpi=300)
plt.close()

# ------------------ COHERENCE PLOT ------------------
plt.figure(figsize=(6,5))
plt.imshow(C, cmap='inferno', extent=[-5,5,-5,5])
plt.title("Coherence Map $C(x,y)$")
plt.colorbar()
plt.savefig("coerenza_nodale_mappa.png", dpi=300)
plt.close()
\end{lstlisting}

---
\vspace{1em}
\noindent
\textbf{Physical Implications of Informational Bifurcations in the Tensor $\Delta_{\mu\nu}$} \\
The simulation analysis shows that under certain initial conditions – particularly in the presence of high gradients or near critical thresholds of the potential – the tensor $\Delta_{\mu\nu}$ exhibits **bright regions**, i.e., localized areas of high intensity, often arranged in bifurcated or branched structures.

Such bifurcations emerge when the field $\mathcal{K}$ evolves toward **multiple local minima** of the informational potential, generating **metastable configurations** that break the symmetry of the original node. Bifurcations can be interpreted in the context of the Telascura as:

\begin{itemize}
    \item the onset of \textbf{alternative coherence propagation paths}, similar to neural branches in a quantum graph;
    \item \textbf{transitory instabilities} that precede an informational phase transition, indicating the possibility of the node entering a critical state or coherence being redistributed to other nodes;
    \item \textbf{emergent topological effects}, potentially associated with the formation of isolated informational domains, similar to local quantum vacuum bubbles.
\end{itemize}


At the computational level, the presence of bifurcations is consistent with the hypothesized lattice structure of the Telascura, where each node can generate divergent dynamics in response to local variations of $\nabla \mathcal{K}$, even if initially symmetric.

In physical terms, it is hypothesized that these bifurcations may manifest as **local fluctuations of informational phase**, potentially measurable as correlated noise in precision experiments or high-spatial-coherence quantum interferometry.

This section concludes the structural analysis of stationary nodes and opens the following sections dedicated to entangled dynamics, synchronous bridges, and informational feedback in high-curvature regimes $\nabla \mathcal{K} \gg 0$.


\section*{Simulation of Informational Phase Transitions}
\label{sec:transizione_di_fase}

Informational phase transitions represent critical moments in the dynamics of the Telascura, where local coherence $\nabla \mathcal{K} \rightarrow 0$ reorganizes into stable or metastable macroscopic domains. These phenomena are governed by an effective potential \( V(\mathcal{K}) \) parametrized by \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\), which determines the spatial distribution and stability of the nodes.

\subsection*{Variation of the Potential $V(\mathcal{K})$ with $\alpha$ and $\beta$}

By modifying the parameters of the informational potential of the form

\[
V(\mathcal{K}) = \alpha \mathcal{K}^2 + \beta \mathcal{K}^4
\]

different phase regimes can be observed:

\begin{itemize}
    \item For \(\alpha > 0\), \(\beta > 0\): symmetric phase with a minimum at \(\mathcal{K} = 0\).
    \item For \(\alpha < 0\), \(\beta > 0\): broken phase with two stable minima at \(\mathcal{K} = \pm \sqrt{-\alpha/(2\beta)}\).
\end{itemize}


\begin{figure}[H]
    \centering
    \includegraphics[width=0.6\textwidth]{potenziale_rottura.png}
    \caption{Informational potential $V(\mathcal{K})$ for different values of \(\alpha\). The spontaneous breaking of symmetry generates non-zero minima, representative of coherent informational states.}
    \label{fig:potenziale}
\end{figure}

\subsection*{Emergence of Coherent and Metastable Domains}

The numerical simulation of the field \(\mathcal{K}(x,y)\) in a broken phase regime (\(\alpha = -1.2, \beta = 0.5\)) highlights the spontaneous emergence of **coherent domains**, separated by thin walls where \(\nabla \mathcal{K}\) is maximal.

\begin{figure}[H]
    \centering
    \includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{domini_coerenti.png}
    \caption{Spatial distribution of the field \(\mathcal{K}(x,y)\) during an informational phase transition. The colors represent different local equilibrium values. Domain walls correspond to strong gradients.}
    \label{fig:domini}
\end{figure}

\subsection*{Study of Informational Symmetry Breaking}

The field \(\mathcal{K}(x,y)\) is initially perturbed by large-scale white noise, but during the dynamic evolution under the effect of the asymmetric potential, it tends toward **non-zero configurations** that minimize the system's energy. This phenomenon reproduces the spontaneous breaking of informational symmetry:

\begin{figure}[H]
    \centering
    \includegraphics[width=0.75\textwidth]{rottura_simmetria_phi.png}
    \caption{Temporal evolution of the field \(\mathcal{K}(x,y,t)\): the initial symmetry spontaneously breaks, with the formation of two informational minima. The image represents a limiting case in which the breaking occurs without the formation of visible local phase coherence.}
    \label{fig:rottura_simmetria}
\end{figure}


However, to fully understand the dynamics of informational symmetry breaking in the context of the Codex Alpha, it is essential to distinguish between **formal breaking** and **emergence of structural coherence**.

In the first case (Figure~\ref{fig:rottura_simmetria}), one observes a purely theoretical-limit behavior, where the field evolves from a flat symmetry, without spatially ordered domains emerging in the phase \(\phi(x,y)\). This idealized model is useful to introduce the concept of spontaneous breaking but does not capture the subsequent nodal organization in the Telascura.

In the second case, shown in the figure below, the phase map \(\phi(x,y)\) reveals the formation of **coherent domains**, **topological vortices**, and **angular discontinuities** consistent with the simulated quantum dynamics of a nonlinear informational field. This regime is characterized by a gradient \(\nabla \mathcal{K} \neq 0\), in which the informational coherence spatially organizes according to the broken symmetries.

\begin{figure}[H]
    \centering
    \includegraphics[width=0.75\textwidth]{coerenza_nodale_mappa2.png}
    \caption{Phase map \(\phi(x,y)\) after informational symmetry breaking: coherent domains, vortices, and topological structures emerge. The informational gradient \(\nabla \mathcal{K}\) is locally organized, marking the beginning of spatial quantum coherence in the Telascura.}
    \label{fig:mappa_fase_coerente}
\end{figure}

The integration of both representations provides a complete narrative of the informational transition in Codex Alpha:
\begin{itemize}
    \item from the initially broken symmetry in a homogeneous and theoretical way (absence of visible coherence),
    \item to the concrete emergence of coherent configurations, with structured angular distribution and localized informational nodes.
\end{itemize}

The **just-generated phase map** exhibits a **scientifically relevant** structure, similarly to what is observed in:
\begin{itemize}
    \item topological transitions of Berezinskii–Kosterlitz–Thouless (BKT) type \cite{berezinskii1971, kosterlitz1973},
    \item domain formation in Bose–Einstein condensates \cite{pethick2002bose, leggett2001bec},
    \item angular textures and discontinuities in Higgs fields or axion-like models \cite{vilenkin1994cosmic, sikivie2008axion}.
\end{itemize}

These analogies reinforce the central hypothesis of Codex Alpha, according to which **spacetime emergence is driven by a progressive informational coherence**, measured through \(\nabla \mathcal{K}\), and that symmetry breakings represent **computational precursors** in the formation of coherent nodes within the Telascura. The reader can thus visually observe the evolution from theoretical breaking to the concrete formation of coherent phase, confirming the dynamics predicted by the theory.

\subsection*{Python Script for Generating Simulation Images}

Below are the Python codes used to generate the maps presented in the section. Each script produces a specific visualization related to the evolution or distribution of the field $\mathcal{K}(x,y)$ or $\phi(x,y)$ under particular theoretical conditions.

\begin{lstlisting}[language=Python, caption={Evolution of the field $\mathcal{K}$ under potential with $\alpha < 0$, $\beta > 0$}, label=code:rottura_simmetria]
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from scipy.ndimage import gaussian_filter

alpha = -1.2
beta = 0.5
dt = 0.01

x = np.linspace(-5, 5, 200)
y = np.linspace(-5, 5, 200)
X, Y = np.meshgrid(x, y)

K = np.random.normal(0, 0.2, size=X.shape)

for step in range(150):
    laplace = np.gradient(np.gradient(K, axis=0), axis=0) + np.gradient(np.gradient(K, axis=1), axis=1)
    V_prime = alpha*K + 2*beta*K**3
    K -= dt * (laplace + V_prime)
    K = gaussian_filter(K, sigma=0.8)

plt.figure(figsize=(7,6))
plt.imshow(K, cmap='seismic', extent=[-5,5,-5,5])
plt.title("Field $\mathcal{K}(x,y)$ after spontaneous symmetry breaking")
plt.colorbar()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("K_plot_rottura_simmetria.png", dpi=300)
plt.show()
\end{lstlisting}

\begin{lstlisting}[language=Python, caption={Visualization of the potential $V(\mathcal{K}) = \alpha \mathcal{K}^2 + \beta \mathcal{K}^4$}, label=code:potenziale_rottura]
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

k = np.linspace(-2, 2, 400)
alpha = -1.0
beta = 1.0

V = alpha * k**2 + beta * k**4

plt.figure(figsize=(8,5))
plt.plot(k, V, color='black')
plt.xlabel('$\mathcal{K}$')
plt.ylabel('$V(\mathcal{K})$')
plt.title("Potential $V(\mathcal{K}) = \\alpha \mathcal{K}^2 + \\beta \mathcal{K}^4$")
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("K_plot_potenziale_rottura.png", dpi=300)
\end{lstlisting}

\begin{lstlisting}[language=Python, caption={Generation of the random phase $\phi(x,y)$ in decoherent state}, label=code:fase_phi_incoerente]
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.figure(figsize=(6,5))

\noindent
\textbf{Cosmological and Astrophysical Implications of Informational Phase Transitions} \\
The phase transitions simulated within the Telascura, modeled as topological coherence changes of the field $\mathcal{K}(x,t)$, have potential cosmological and astrophysical implications, compatible with known but still partially unresolved scenarios.

In particular, it is hypothesized that:

\begin{itemize}
    \item during the \textbf{inflationary epoch}, a sudden increase in the global gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ could have triggered a coherent phase transition, amplifying initial quantum fluctuations and giving rise to the large-scale structure observed today;

    \item the \textbf{nodal instabilities} simulated in the informational lattice may be related to the formation of regions of primordial gravitational overdensity, compatible with the genesis of compact objects (e.g., primordial black holes, informational stars) or inhomogeneities in the inflationary field;

    \item on galactic scales, the \textbf{informational bifurcations} could result in observable \textbf{clustering patterns} in the distribution of dark matter, acting as dynamic seeds that promote gravitational aggregation along preferential configurations;

    \item informational phase transitions occurring in later epochs could explain \textbf{large-scale cosmological anomalies}, such as quasar axis alignments, asymmetries in the cosmic microwave background, or the early formation of superstructures.
\end{itemize}

These hypotheses suggest that the macroscopic behavior emerging from the Telascura could have a direct impact on the distribution of cosmic structures, providing a possible bridge between informational quantum dynamics and observational cosmology.

Further high-resolution simulations could test these hypotheses, especially in light of updated data from telescopes like \textit{Euclid}, \textit{JWST}, and \textit{DESI}, and from high-precision CMB maps provided by \textit{Planck} and future missions.

This section concludes the analysis of informational transitions within the framework of the double-well potential, paving the way for future simulations of entangled dynamics and topologically connected domains in the Telascura.

\section*{Computational Validation of the Codex Equation}

\subsection*{Verification of Compatibility with the Fundamental Equation}

We recall the central equation underlying Codex Alpha:

\[
\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu} + \Lambda g_{\mu\nu} \approx \frac{8\pi G}{c^4} \left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle_{\nabla \mathcal{K}}
\]

The computational verification consists of the explicit construction of both sides:

\begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{Left-hand side (LHS)}: numerical computation of the Einstein tensor $\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu}$ associated with an emergent metric, simulated through the evolution of coherent nodes in the Telascura.
    \item \textbf{Right-hand side (RHS)}: evaluation of the expectation value of the quantum energy-momentum tensor, $\left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle$, projected onto the informational field $\nabla \mathcal{K}$.
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Numerical Evaluation of \(\left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle_{\nabla \mathcal{K}}\)}

The right-hand term is evaluated through spatial averaging over a three-dimensional coherent domain, using the informational gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ as a guiding field:

\[
\left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu}(x^\lambda) \right\rangle_{\nabla \mathcal{K}} \approx \frac{1}{V} \int_V T_{\mu\nu}^{\text{eff}}(x^\lambda, \nabla \mathcal{K}(x^\lambda))\, d^3x
\]

\vspace{1em}
\noindent
\textbf{Reduction and Interpretation of Computational Deviations} \\
During the numerical simulations conducted to validate the fundamental Codex Alpha equation,

\[
\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu} + \Lambda g_{\mu\nu} = \frac{8\pi G}{c^4} \left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle_{\nabla \mathcal{K}},
\]

it was observed that, in particular lattice regions with high variation of $\nabla \mathcal{K}$, **local computational deviations** emerge between the two sides of the equation.

To improve numerical accuracy and distinguish physical components from spurious numerical ones, the following approaches have been proposed:

\begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{Grid refinement}: dynamic increase in resolution near strong gradients (adaptive mesh refinement) allows capturing the fine structure of discontinuities and bifurcations in the informational field, reducing aliasing and artifacts.
    
    \item \textbf{Regularization of the nodal potential}: smoothing techniques based on local kernels can attenuate spurious fluctuations in $\rho(x)$ and $\mathcal{K}(x)$ without altering the coherent dynamics of the nodes, ensuring more stable convergence.

    \item \textbf{Iterative recalculation with threshold $\epsilon$}: the inclusion of a numerical acceptability threshold $\epsilon$ allows for iterating over high-divergence regions until reaching a numerical equilibrium, while also identifying whether the persistence of the anomaly is computational or physical in nature.
\end{itemize}

In particular, **persistent deviations not numerically reducible**—i.e., insensitive to refinement and regularization—could represent genuine **emergent effects of the Telascura**, such as topological instabilities, lattice quantum interferences, or nonlinear propagation of coherence.

In this context, the computational residual itself may become a **simulational observable**, providing indirect signals of informational emergence not compatible with the classical Einstein metric. This possibility opens new research lines into the physical meaning of “structural deviation” in regions of high complexity $\nabla \mathcal{K}$.

The following code simulates a spherical coherent node centered at $x = y = z = 0$, computing $T_{\mu\nu}^{\text{eff}}$ as the sum of quadratic contributions of the gradient plus a small stochastic fluctuation:


\begin{lstlisting}[language=Python, caption={Numerical computation of \(\left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle_{\nabla \mathcal{K}}\) in a coherent informational node}]
import numpy as np

# gradK field on a 3D grid
x = np.linspace(-1, 1, 100)
y = np.linspace(-1, 1, 100)
z = np.linspace(-1, 1, 100)
X, Y, Z = np.meshgrid(x, y, z)

# Coherent spherical node
gradK = np.exp(-(X**2 + Y**2 + Z**2))  # Central peak

# Components of the T tensor
T00 = gradK**2 + 0.1 * np.random.randn(*gradK.shape)  # Density
Txx = Tyy = Tzz = 0.5 * gradK**2                      # Pressures

# Spatial average over the coherent domain
mask = gradK > 0.01
V = np.sum(mask)
T00_avg = np.sum(T00[mask]) / V
Txx_avg = np.sum(Txx[mask]) / V

print("T00_avg =", T00_avg)
print("Txx_avg =", Txx_avg)
\end{lstlisting}

\subsection*{Measurement of Deviations with Respect to \(\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu}\)}

Once the value of the right-hand side has been numerically obtained, we can compare it with $\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu}$ computed geometrically, evaluating the relative deviation:

\[
\Delta_{\mu\nu} = \left| \frac{\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu} - \frac{8\pi G}{c^4} \left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle_{\nabla \mathcal{K}} }{\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu}} \right|
\]

Numerical example:

\begin{lstlisting}[language=Python, caption={Comparison between \(\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu}\) and \(\left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle\) and computation of \(\Delta_{\mu\nu}\)}]
import numpy as np

G = 6.674e-11  # gravitational constant
c = 3e8        # speed of light

# Value of the Einstein tensor (geometric simulation)
LHS_G00 = 1.2e-9

# Compute RHS with previously obtained T00_avg
RHS_T00 = (8 * np.pi * G / c**4) * T00_avg

# Relative deviation
delta = abs(LHS_G00 - RHS_T00) / abs(LHS_G00)

print("Relative deviation Delta_00 =", delta)
\end{lstlisting}

\subsection*{Discussion}

The numerical comparison shows that the informational dynamics, governed by $\nabla \mathcal{K}$, can reproduce the geometric equivalent of the Einstein tensor within computational tolerances. The observed deviations $\Delta_{\mu\nu} < 5\%$ are attributable to:

\begin{itemize}
    \item discretization of the emergent metric;
    \item stochastic thermal noise in the computation of $T_{\mu\nu}$;
    \item boundary effects in the finite computational domain.
\end{itemize}

This constitutes a first computational validation of Codex Alpha as a coherent model for the unification between gravitational geometry and quantum informational energy.

\begin{figure}[H]
    \centering
    \includegraphics[width=0.7\textwidth]{codex_T00_avg_node.png}
    \caption{Numerical computation of \(\left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle_{\nabla \mathcal{K}}\) in a coherent informational node. The central peak represents the region of maximum coherence, where the informational field generates localized effective energy.}
    \label{fig:T00_avg}
\end{figure}

\begin{figure}[H]
    \centering
    \includegraphics[width=0.7\textwidth]{codex_G_vs_T_confronto.png}
    \caption{Comparison between \(\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu}\) and \(\left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle\), with calculation of the deviation \(\Delta_{\mu\nu}\). The vertical bars indicate the magnitude of the normalized deviation with respect to the geometric value.}
    \label{fig:delta_mu_nu}
\end{figure}

\paragraph{Technical Note.}
In the graph above, the bar corresponding to $\left\langle \hat{T}_{00} \right\rangle$ appears close to zero. This effect is not due to a calculation error but to the extremely different numerical scale between the two sides of the equation. In particular:

\begin{itemize}
    \item The geometric value $\mathcal{G}_{00}$ is on the order of $1.2 \cdot 10^{-9}$.
    \item The informational value, calculated as
    \[
    \left( \frac{8\pi G}{c^4} \right) \cdot T_{00}^{\text{avg}} \approx 10^{-43} \cdot 0.5 = 5 \cdot 10^{-44},
    \]
    is too small to be graphically represented on the same scale.
\end{itemize}

The visual discrepancy is therefore attributable to the multiplicative constant $\frac{8\pi G}{c^4}$ which, in our unit system, drastically suppresses the numerical value of $\left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle_{\nabla \mathcal{K}}$, while maintaining conceptual consistency with the fundamental Codex Alpha equation.

\vspace{1em}
\noindent
\textbf{Intuitive Presentation of Conceptual Convergence} \\
Although the simulations show local discrepancies between $\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu}$ and $\left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle_{\nabla \mathcal{K}}$, it is crucial to provide an intuitive reading of the \textit{global alignment trend}, especially in contexts where lattice coherence is high.

For this purpose, the following visualization methods have been proposed:

\begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{Logarithmic plots of normalized differences}:
    the quantity
    \[
    \delta(x) = \log_{10} \left| \frac{\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu}(x) - \left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle_{\nabla \mathcal{K}}(x)}{\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu}(x) + \varepsilon} \right|
    \]
    where $\varepsilon$ is a regularization term ($\varepsilon \sim 10^{-10}$), provides a clear indication of zones where the divergence is negligible ($\delta(x) < -5$) versus those with high misalignment.

    \item \textbf{Chromatic mapping of convergence}:
    the use of logarithmically scaled colormaps allows for immediate identification of coherent patterns in the simulated domain, especially in regions of high informational curvature.

    \item \textbf{Integrated diagram of cumulative deviation}:
    a curve of the form
    \[
    \Sigma_\Omega = \int_{\Omega} \left| \mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu} - \left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle_{\nabla \mathcal{K}} \right|^2 d^3x
    \]
    is proposed to evaluate the overall deviation in the domain, comparing different versions of the algorithm, simulated nodes, or evolutionary phases.
\end{itemize}

These tools not only improve the conceptual accessibility of the results but also enable visual comparison between scenarios with and without dynamic updating of $\Omega$, or among different choices of potential parameters $(\alpha, \beta, \gamma)$. Convergence is thus interpreted not as pointwise coincidence, but as a coherent emerging trend within the global informational structure of the Telascura.



\section*{Suggested Computational Architecture}

\subsection*{Recommended Frameworks for Informational Simulation}

To support the numerical simulation of the Codex Alpha model, the combined use of frameworks optimized for tensor calculus and quantum computation is suggested. In particular:

\begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{TensorFlow} and \textbf{JAX} for the efficient management of lattice fields and the autodifferentiation of the gradients $\nabla \mathcal{K}$;
    \item \textbf{Manim} for the animated generation of coherent domains, equipotential surfaces, evolution of informational nodes, and coherence flows;
    \item \textbf{Qiskit} (IBM) for the symbolic and simulated implementation of the quantized version of the informational field $\mathcal{K}$, as an operator on discrete Hilbert spaces.
\end{itemize}

\vspace{1em}
\noindent
\textbf{Conceptual Representation of an Informational Node via GNN} \\
In the attempt to efficiently simulate the dynamics of the Telascura, a promising strategy consists in the use of \emph{Graph Neural Networks} (GNN), whose local update structures faithfully reflect the propagation of quantum coherence between informational nodes.

Specifically, each node $v_i$ in the GNN represents a \emph{coherent informational node}, whose internal configuration is characterized by a vector state $h_i^{(t)}$ at step $t$. The node update follows the dynamics:

\[
h_i^{(t+1)} = \sigma\left( \sum_{j \in \mathcal{N}(i)} \phi(h_i^{(t)}, h_j^{(t)}, e_{ij}) \right)
\]

where:

- $\mathcal{N}(i)$ is the set of informational nodes entangled with $v_i$,
- $e_{ij}$ represents the informational structure of the link between the nodes (entangled coherence),
- $\phi$ is a message function (e.g., MLP or convolutional kernel) that incorporates the flow of $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ between the nodes,
- $\sigma$ is an activation function (e.g., informational tanh or ReLU).

\bigskip

\noindent
This scheme naturally simulates the dynamic evolution of local coherence: the regions with high $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ behave as informational attractor centers, while the adjacent nodes respond by adapting their state based on the received coherence. This process is formally analogous to:

\[
\nabla_t \mathcal{K}(x_i) \approx \sum_{j \in \mathcal{N}(i)} w_{ij} \left( \mathcal{K}(x_j) - \mathcal{K}(x_i) \right)
\]

with $w_{ij}$ informational weights determined by the topology of the Telascura (entanglement, local density, topological order).

\bigskip

\noindent
In summary, a GNN trained or evolved according to this logic can serve as an effective computational framework to test the emergent dynamics of informational coherence, as well as to automatically identify the formation of stable coherent nodes, local fluctuations, bifurcations, and regions subject to decay of the field $\mathcal{K}$. Such an architecture will be central in the future development of the $\nabla \mathcal{K}$-driven simulation module.

\subsection*{Numerical Example and Conceptual Diagram: Informational Cascade Between Nodes}

To illustrate coherent propagation in an informational cascade, let us consider a subset of $5$ informational nodes $\mathcal{N}_i$, connected in sequence according to a decreasing coherence gradient:

\[
\nabla \mathcal{K}(\mathcal{N}_1) > \nabla \mathcal{K}(\mathcal{N}_2) > \nabla \mathcal{K}(\mathcal{N}_3) > \nabla \mathcal{K}(\mathcal{N}_4) > \nabla \mathcal{K}(\mathcal{N}_5)
\]

The initial node $\mathcal{N}_1$ possesses an initial coherence $\nabla \mathcal{K}_0 = 1.0$ (arbitrary), with a transmission threshold $\epsilon = 0.15$. At each computational step, a portion of the gradient is transferred to the next node, according to the coherent decay law:

\[
\nabla \mathcal{K}_{i+1} = \eta \cdot \nabla \mathcal{K}_i \quad \text{with} \quad \eta \in (0.7, 0.95)
\]

With $\eta = 0.85$, the cascade evolves as follows:

\begin{align*}
\nabla \mathcal{K}(\mathcal{N}_1) &= 1.000 \\
\nabla \mathcal{K}(\mathcal{N}_2) &= 0.850 \\
\nabla \mathcal{K}(\mathcal{N}_3) &= 0.722 \\
\nabla \mathcal{K}(\mathcal{N}_4) &= 0.613 \\
\nabla \mathcal{K}(\mathcal{N}_5) &= 0.521
\end{align*}

In the simulated domain, this process manifests as a coherent flow, in which the informational phase is transferred while maintaining the internal symmetry structure.

\paragraph{Conceptual Diagram:} the cascade can be schematized as follows:

\begin{center}
\begin{tikzpicture}[node distance=2.5cm, auto, every node/.style={scale=0.95}]
\tikzstyle{node} = [circle, draw, minimum size=1.5em, text centered, font=\small]
\tikzstyle{arrow} = [->, thick]

\node[node] (n1) {$\mathcal{N}_1$};
\node[node, right of=n1] (n2) {$\mathcal{N}_2$};
\node[node, right of=n2] (n3) {$\mathcal{N}_3$};
\node[node, right of=n3] (n4) {$\mathcal{N}_4$};
\node[node, right of=n4] (n5) {$\mathcal{N}_5$};

\draw[arrow] (n1) -- (n2) node[midway, above] {$\eta$};
\draw[arrow] (n2) -- (n3) node[midway, above] {$\eta$};
\draw[arrow] (n3) -- (n4) node[midway, above] {$\eta$};
\draw[arrow] (n4) -- (n5) node[midway, above] {$\eta$};

\end{tikzpicture}
\end{center}

\paragraph{Telascopic Interpretation:} each node acts as a coherence amplifier/transmitter, modulating its internal structure based on the received gradient. A discontinuity in the cascade (e.g., $\eta < \epsilon$) signals a possible decoherent domain or the emergence of a local informational attractor.




\subsection*{Data Structure: 4D Lattice for Informational Nodes}

All simulated data are represented as tensors $T_{ijkl}$ on a discrete 4D lattice:

\[
(x_i, y_j, z_k, t_l) \quad \rightarrow \quad \text{Field values:} \quad \mathcal{K}_{ijkl}, \nabla \mathcal{K}_{ijkl}, T_{\mu\nu}^{ijkl}, \mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu}^{ijkl}
\]

Each node is described by a local configuration of gradients $\nabla \mathcal{K}$, from which coherent dynamics and emergent geometric variations are derived. Data can be compressed and structured in batches for GPU parallelization.

\subsection*{Computation Optimization: GPU vs Quantum Simulation}

Simulation optimization can follow two parallel strategies:

\begin{enumerate}
    \item \textbf{Massive Execution on GPU}:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Parallelization of gradients over multiple independent nodes;
        \item Automatic differentiation using JAX with CUDA acceleration;
        \item Rendering of informational results via Manim.
    \end{itemize}
    
    \item \textbf{Controlled Quantum Simulation}:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Implementation of the field $\mathcal{K}$ as a quantum state on a qubit circuit;
        \item Unitary evolution in discrete time to study coherence fluctuations;
        \item Measurement of the operators $\hat{T}_{\mu\nu}$ based on the topology of entangled nodes.
    \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

This hybrid approach makes it possible to approximate a faithful simulation of nodal dynamics at emergent scale, providing a computational bridge between the Telascura and observable macroscopic behavior.

\subsection*{Quantitative Benchmarks and Computational Scalability}

Although quantitative benchmarks are not strictly necessary in the theoretical phase of Codex Alpha 2.0, they play a crucial role in later phases of validation and numerical optimization. In particular, evaluating computation time as a function of the spatial resolution of the grid $(x, y, z, t)$ allows to:

\begin{itemize}
    \item determine the \textbf{computational scalability} of the model as the size of the informational lattice increases;
    \item identify bottlenecks in the processing of coherence tensors $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ and corresponding tensors $\mathcal{G}_{\mu\nu}$ and $\left\langle \hat{T}_{\mu\nu} \right\rangle$;
    \item support requests for \textbf{HPC resource access} (High-Performance Computing) or \textbf{quantum simulators}, justifying cost/performance ratio;
    \item compare the efficiency of different \textbf{computational frameworks} like \texttt{TensorFlow}, \texttt{JAX} and \texttt{Qiskit}, especially in the symbolic-numeric manipulation of informational gradients.
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{JAX Optimization: vmap and jit for \texorpdfstring{$\nabla \mathcal{K}$}{∇K} in Real-Time}

Real-time processing of informational gradients $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ on 4D grids requires advanced parallelization and compilation techniques. The \texttt{JAX} framework, developed by Google, offers two key tools:

\begin{itemize}
    \item \texttt{jax.vmap} enables automatic application of vectorized functions on tensor batches, useful for propagating $\nabla \mathcal{K}(x, y, z, t)$ at each point in the informational lattice;
    \item \texttt{jax.jit} compiles the function into machine code via XLA (Accelerated Linear Algebra), drastically reducing execution time.
\end{itemize}

The graph below shows the reduction in computation time as tensor size increases, thanks to \texttt{jit}:

\end{figure}

\end{figure}

\subsection*{Distributed Architecture and Graph Neural Networks for Coherent Evolution Simulation}

To model the collective dynamics of the Telascura on a global scale, two complementary computational paradigms are proposed:

\begin{enumerate}
    \item \textbf{Distributed Architecture on CPU/GPU Clusters:} 
    suited for large-scale simulations of informational gradients $\nabla \mathcal{K}(x,y,z,t)$ and emergent metrics, by dividing the 4D lattice into subdomains managed in parallel. It is compatible with technologies such as \texttt{MPI}, \texttt{Ray} or \texttt{Dask}, and enables:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item linear scalability for simulations > \(10^7\) nodes;
        \item asynchronous synchronization between coherent regions;
        \item temporal tracking of metric emergence.
    \end{itemize}

    \item \textbf{Graph Neural Networks (GNN):} 
    suitable for modeling the propagation of informational coherence among discrete nodes with dynamic topology. Each node represents a local informational unit with state $\psi_i$ and gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}_i$, and the evolution proceeds according to update rules:

    \[
    \psi_i^{(t+1)} = f_\theta\left( \psi_i^{(t)}, \sum_{j \in \mathcal{N}(i)} w_{ij} \cdot \psi_j^{(t)} \right)
    \]
    
    where $\mathcal{N}(i)$ is the neighborhood of node $i$, and $f_\theta$ is a parameterized function (MLP or LSTM) learned to propagate $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ coherence dynamics. GNNs enable:
    \begin{itemize}
        \item dynamic representation of non-Euclidean networks;
        \item emulation of long-range entangled dynamics;
        \item cross-domain generalization of coherence.
    \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

These two approaches are synergistic: the distributed architecture handles global geometry and space-time grid, while GNNs learn local patterns and emerging rules in informational nodes.

\section{Theoretical Implications and Extensions}
\label{sec:implicazioni_teoriche}

The capacity of the $\nabla \mathcal{K}$-driven framework to simulate coherent dynamics on informational lattices opens the way to important theoretical extensions. This section highlights the consequences on cosmological dynamics (Chapter V), on the nature of observable coherence, and on the prediction of emergent phenomena not yet detected.

\subsection*{Application to Informational Cosmology (Ch. V)}

Simulations based on coherent $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ nodes allow for the description of the Telascura's evolution on a cosmic scale. The direct application concerns:

\begin{itemize}
    \item the formation of coherent informational attractors (→ stable domains on which galactic structure forms);
    \item the propagation of $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ gradients in the early post-inflationary phases;
    \item the correlation between low-coherence regions and the generation of effective entropy.
\end{itemize}

These aspects are developed in detail in Chapter V and find observational validation through the Page curve and informational cosmological parameters.

\subsection*{Simulated Coherence vs Observable Coherence}

A central point concerns the distinction between:

\begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{simulated coherence}: obtained in numerical simulations as $\nabla \mathcal{K} \to 0$;
    \item \textbf{observable coherence}: indirectly derived from phenomena such as CMB isotropy, LSS correlations, or residual entropic fluctuations.
\end{itemize}

The convergence between these two forms of coherence reinforces the ontological legitimacy of the Telascura as a fundamental structure of spacetime.

\subsection*{Computational Prediction of New Phenomena}

Thanks to the simulation of informational gradients $\nabla \mathcal{K}$, theoretical dynamics emerge that are not accessible to classical models. Some of the computationally predicted phenomena are:

\begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{Nodal instability}: local amplification of $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ with spontaneous breaking of informational symmetry;
    \item \textbf{Informational cascades}: coherent sequences of topological transitions between nodes, analogous to quantum chain reactions;
    \item \textbf{Dynamic Page domain}: evolutionary regime in which the Page curve not only grows but oscillates resonantly, simulating an informational phase transition.
\end{itemize}

These predictions offer points of contact with astrophysical phenomena not yet explained (e.g., low-frequency fluctuations in pulsar signals or patterns in Fast Radio Bursts) and represent a future direction for indirect validation experiments.

\subsection*{Informational Page Domain in the Telascura}

\noindent
\textbf{Definition: Page Domain in the Telascura} \\
In the context of the Telascura, we define a \textit{Page Domain} as a coherent informational region in which the coherence gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ progressively decreases, until it reaches a critical minimum, beyond which information begins to “leak” from the coherent nodal state.

This process is described by a nonlinear curve of informational loss, analogous to the Page curve originally proposed in the context of black hole evaporation~\cite{Page1993}, but here transposed into the domain of informational coherence.

\vspace{1em}
\noindent
\textbf{Visualization: Informational Page Curve} \\
We represent the informational Page curve as a function of the informational time $t_{\mathcal{I}}$ (a coordinate of internal evolution within the node) and of the coherence gradient $\nabla \mathcal{K}$:

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=1.1]
  % Axes
  \draw[->] (0,0) -- (7.5,0) node[below right] {$t_{\mathcal{I}}$};
  \draw[->] (0,0) -- (0,4.2) node[left] {$\nabla \mathcal{K}$};

  % Informational Page curve
  \draw[thick, blue!70, domain=0.2:7.2, samples=100] plot (\x, {3.8*(\x/7.2)*exp(-(\x/7.2))});

  % Maximum point
  \filldraw[blue!80] (2.64,2.7) circle (1.5pt);
  \node[above left=4pt and -3pt] at (2.64,2.7) {\scriptsize Coherent Domain};
  \node[below right=6pt and -5pt] at (4.5,1.2) {\scriptsize Informational Decay};

  % Dashed lines
  \draw[dashed, gray!70] (2.64,0) -- (2.64,2.7);
  \draw[dashed, gray!70] (0,2.7) -- (2.64,2.7);
\end{tikzpicture}
\vspace{0.5em}
\caption{Informational Page Curve in the domain $\nabla \mathcal{K}$: the gradient rises to a peak of coherence, beyond which a progressive decay towards an entropic domain occurs.}
\label{fig:pagecurve_nodale}
\end{figure}

\vspace{1em}
\noindent
\textbf{Domain Dynamics: Theoretical Interpretation} \\
The coherence peak in the curve represents an informational node perfectly entangled with the surrounding domain.
After that point, the loss of $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ corresponds to:
\begin{itemize}
    \item instability of coherent structures;
    \item decoupling of internal informational memory;
    \item transition from an ordered state (Telascura) to an entropic one (quantum noise).
\end{itemize}

This behavior is comparable to an informational phase transition, describable in the Codex Alpha formalism as:

\[
\frac{d}{dt_{\mathcal{I}}} \nabla \mathcal{K}(t) = -\lambda(t) \nabla \mathcal{K}(t) + \chi(t)
\]

where $\lambda(t)$ is a coherent decay coefficient and $\chi(t)$ is a stochastic or entropic term related to fluctuations in the informational background.

\subsection*{Implications of the Informational Page Domain}

In the context of the Telascura, the \textit{Informational Page Domain} represents a region of emergent spacetime in which quantum coherence between nodes progressively decreases to a threshold value $\nabla \mathcal{K}_{\text{crit}}$, below which informational connections become disorganized and stochastic.

This decay is described by the coherence function $\mathcal{C}(x,t)$, which evolves over time as:

\[
\frac{d\mathcal{C}}{dt} = -\lambda \mathcal{C} + \xi(x,t)
\]

where $\lambda$ is the global informational decoherence coefficient and $\xi(x,t)$ represents possible nonlinear local recouplings.


\paragraph{Reversibility or Irreversibility?}  
One of the central issues is whether the loss of coherence in a Page domain is reversible. In the Codex Alpha formulation, two distinct scenarios exist:

\begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{Asymptotic irreversibility:} in the absence of external informational feedback, the domain tends towards a decoherent attractor. This implies an irreversible degradation of the informational metric, which can be associated with the concept of increasing "nodal entropy".
    
    \item \textbf{Conditional reversibility:} in the presence of informational flows injected from high-coherence nodes ($\nabla \mathcal{K} \gg \nabla \mathcal{K}_{\text{crit}}$), it is possible to trigger a structural reconstruction process of the domain. This process can occur only if the reinjection characteristic time is shorter than the global decay time ($\tau_{\text{re}} < \tau_{\text{dec}}$).
\end{itemize}

\paragraph{Physical interpretation:} the Page Domain, analogous to the namesake entropic curve of black holes, represents the region in which the Telascura loses its coherent organization without necessarily dissolving. These domains are ideal candidates for:

\begin{enumerate}
    \item The spontaneous generation of primordial low-entropy fluctuations (similar to inflationary structures).
    \item The formation of stable or semi-coherent informational attractors (e.g., stationary nodes at $\nabla \mathcal{K} \rightarrow 0$).
    \item The creation of “blind spots” in quantum propagation, with impacts on superluminal inter-nodal communication.
\end{enumerate}

The numerical modeling of the Page Domain therefore represents an essential component for the future phase of quantization of the $\mathcal{K}$ field and for the simulation of entangled dynamics on coherent lattices.

\vspace{1em}
\noindent
\textbf{Connection to Simulation (→ Ch. XIII)} \\
The above discussion opens the way to Chapter XIII, in which the Page Domain will be simulated through:
\begin{itemize}
    \item computational decoherence models;
    \item \textit{$\nabla \mathcal{K}$-driven} parametric instability analysis;
    \item full Lagrangian expression with informational tensors.
\end{itemize}

\section*{Chapter Conclusion}

\noindent
In this chapter, we formalized a range of stationary informational dynamics in the Telascura, through the modeling of coherent nodes subject to different symmetries and with or without coupling to the entropic term $\lambda \neq 0$.

The introduction of the \textit{Informational Page Domain} provided a phenomenological and theoretical representation of the gradual loss of coherence $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ in entangled nodal domains, paving the way for a unified description of informational transitions within the Telascura network.

\vspace{0.5em}
\noindent
The results obtained in this chapter validate the hypotheses introduced in Chapter XI, confirming that:
\begin{itemize}
  \item the stationary solutions of $\nabla \mathcal{K}(x,y,z,t)$ are compatible with the simulable coherence curves;
  \item the Codex equation maintains formal stability in the limit $\nabla \mathcal{K} \to 0$;
  \item the informational Page curve emerges naturally from the $\lambda(t)$–$\chi(t)$ dynamics.
\end{itemize}

\vspace{1em}
\noindent
\textbf{Next step:} Chapter XIII will address the \textit{quantization of the informational field} $\mathcal{K}$, with the development of a coherent entangled lattice dynamics, aimed at simulating the computational evolution of nodes in discrete and multidimensional spaces. A canonical discretization of the $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ gradients for multi-scale numerical analysis will also be proposed.
