\paragraph{Scale Progression: From Cluster to Filament}
Having established the manifestation of informational gradients at cluster scales (400 kpc), we now examine their action at intermediate cosmic scales through the remarkable discovery of a rotating galaxy filament.

\subsubsection*{External case study 2: MeerKAT MIGHTEE-Hi 15 Mpc Rotating Galaxy Filament - Direct Telascura Validation}

Recent observational evidence from the MeerKAT International Giga-Hertz Tiered Extragalactic Exploration (MIGHTEE-Hi) survey provides extraordinary direct validation of the large-scale informational coherence predicted by the Telascura framework. The discovery by \cite{Tudorache2025} of a 15 Mpc rotating galaxy filament at redshift $z = 0.032$ represents one of the most compelling empirical confirmations of the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradient acting as an organizing principle across cosmic scales.

\paragraph{Observational Discovery and Dataset}

The MIGHTEE-Hi survey, conducted using the MeerKAT radio telescope array consisting of 64 offset-Gregorian dishes with 13.5m main reflectors, detected a remarkable cosmic structure in the COSMOS field \cite{Tudorache2025}. The survey utilized the L-band receiver (900-1670 MHz) with spectral line observations in the L2 band (1310-1420 MHz), achieving 32,768 channels with a channel width of 26.5 kHz, corresponding to 5.5 km s$^{-1}$ velocity resolution at $z = 0$.

The discovered structure consists of 14 Hi-selected galaxies forming a coherent filamentary configuration with the following precise observational parameters:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Hi filament length:} 1.7 Mpc (direct Hi structure)
\item \textbf{Cosmic web filament length:} 15.4 Mpc (traced by optical galaxies)
\item \textbf{Filament width:} $\sim$117,000 light years ($\sim$36 kpc)
\item \textbf{Filament thickness:} 0.8-1.0 Mpc (cylindrical approximation)
\item \textbf{Redshift range:} $z = 0.031-0.032$
\item \textbf{Velocity range:} 9,230-9,700 km s$^{-1}$
\item \textbf{Velocity dispersion:} $\sigma_v = 140$ km s$^{-1}$
\item \textbf{Hi mass range:} $\log_{10}(M_{\text{Hi}}/M_{\odot}) = 8.1-9.6$
\item \textbf{Stellar mass range:} $\log_{10}(M_*/M_{\odot}) = 7.4-10.2$
\end{itemize}

The Hi mass of each galaxy was calculated using the standard relation \cite{Tudorache2025}:
\begin{equation}
\left(\frac{M_{\text{Hi}}}{M_{\odot}}\right) = 2.356 \times 10^5 \left(\frac{D_L}{1+z}\right)^2 \left(\frac{S}{\text{Jy km s}^{-1}}\right)^2 \left(\frac{\text{Mpc}}{\text{Mpc}}\right)^2
\end{equation}
where $D_L$ is the cosmological luminosity distance and $S$ is the integrated Hi flux density from moment-0 maps.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{tudorache_filament_map.png}
\caption{Sky distribution of the 14 Hi galaxies (red circles) forming the 1.7 Mpc filamentary structure, embedded within the larger 15.4 Mpc cosmic web filament traced by optical galaxies from SDSS and DESI surveys. The linear coherent arrangement demonstrates the manifestation of primordial $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients preserved across cosmic time. Adapted from \cite{Tudorache2025}.}
\label{fig:tudorache_filament_map}
\end{figure}

\paragraph{Cosmic Web Characterization and Telascura Interpretation}

The cosmic web skeleton was determined using the Disperse algorithm \cite{Sousbie2011}, a topological method based on discrete Morse theory that computes the cosmic web structure using Delaunay Tessellation Field Estimator. The algorithm utilized galaxy distributions from SDSS DR17 \cite{Abdurro2022} and DESI Legacy Data \cite{Dey2019,Adame2024} with a stellar mass cut of $M_* > 10^9 M_{\odot}$ to isolate the main filamentary structure. A 5$\sigma$ significance level was adopted to ensure robust filament identification.

In the Telascura framework, this observed structure represents a direct manifestation of the informational gradient $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ acting as a primordial organizing field. The 15.4 Mpc cosmic web filament corresponds to a large-scale coherence domain within the Telascura network, where informational nodes maintain structural integrity across cosmological distances. The embedded 1.7 Mpc Hi structure represents a high-coherence sub-network where the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradient has preserved the primordial informational imprint with exceptional fidelity.

The linear arrangement of galaxies along the filament spine, with their remarkably small velocity dispersion ($\sigma_v = 140$ km s$^{-1}$), indicates that this structure formed under the influence of a coherent informational field rather than through stochastic gravitational processes alone. This is precisely the signature expected from Telascura dynamics, where informational coherence guides matter distribution along preferred trajectories defined by $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{tudorache_cosmic_web_skeleton.png}
\caption{Cosmic web skeleton derived using the Disperse algorithm, showing the 15.4 Mpc filament (thick line) connecting multiple nodes. The Hi galaxies (red points) are preferentially located along the filament spine, demonstrating the role of large-scale structure as a guide for galaxy formation. This topology is consistent with the Telascura network architecture predicted by the Codex Alpha framework. Adapted from \cite{Tudorache2025}.}
\label{fig:tudorache_cosmic_web}
\end{figure}

\paragraph{Spin-Filament Alignment: Quantitative Evidence for $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ Coherence}

The most compelling evidence for Telascura dynamics comes from the unprecedented degree of spin-filament alignment observed in this structure. Using a thin-disk approximation \cite{Leealignments2007}, the spin unit vector of each galaxy was characterized in local spherical coordinates:

\begin{align}
\hat{L}_r &= \cos i \\
\hat{L}_\theta &= \sin i \sin \text{PA} \\
\hat{L}_\phi &= \sin i \cos \text{PA}
\end{align}

where PA is the position angle and $i$ is the inclination angle determined from $g$-band photometry using $\cos(i) = b/a$, with $b$ and $a$ being the minor and major axes of the fitted ellipse.

The spin-filament alignment was quantified through the cosine of the angle $\psi$ between the galaxy spin vector $\mathbf{L}$ and the filament vector $\mathbf{f}$:

\begin{equation}
\cos\psi = \frac{f_x \cdot \hat{L}_x + f_y \cdot \hat{L}_y + f_z \cdot \hat{L}_z}{|\mathbf{f}|}
\end{equation}

The results reveal extraordinary alignment statistics that far exceed predictions from standard cosmological simulations:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Hi galaxy alignment:} $\langle|\cos\psi|\rangle = 0.64 \pm 0.05$
\item \textbf{Optical galaxy alignment:} $\langle|\cos\psi|\rangle = 0.55 \pm 0.05$
\item \textbf{Statistical significance:} $> 5\sigma$ deviation from cosmological simulations
\item \textbf{Alignment strength:} 2-3 times stronger than typical filament-galaxy correlations
\end{itemize}

In the Codex Alpha interpretation, this exceptional alignment represents direct observational evidence of the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradient acting as a coherence field that preserves angular momentum correlations across the Telascura network. The stronger alignment observed in Hi galaxies ($\langle|\cos\psi|\rangle = 0.64$) compared to optical galaxies ($\langle|\cos\psi|\rangle = 0.55$) suggests that gas-rich systems are more sensitive to informational gradients, consistent with the Telascura model where Hi gas acts as a tracer of the underlying informational field.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{tudorache_spin_alignment.png}
\caption{Distribution of spin-filament alignment parameter $|\cos\psi|$ for Hi galaxies (right panel) and optical galaxies (left panel). The Hi sample shows a pronounced peak at $|\cos\psi| \sim 0.64$, indicating strong preferential alignment with the filament orientation. This exceptional coherence provides direct evidence for the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradient acting as an organizing field in the Telascura framework. Adapted from \cite{Tudorache2025}.}
\label{fig:tudorache_spin_alignment}
\end{figure}

\paragraph{Filament Rotation: Evidence for Large-Scale Angular Momentum Transfer}

Perhaps the most remarkable discovery is the detection of coherent rotation of galaxies around the filament spine, making this structure one of the largest rotating systems ever observed. The rotation was detected through systematic velocity gradients perpendicular to the filament axis, with galaxies showing orbital motion around the central spine.

The rotation curve analysis revealed:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Rotation amplitude:} $\sim 100-200$ km s$^{-1}$ at 0.5 Mpc from spine
\item \textbf{Rotation scale:} Coherent motion detected out to $\sim 1$ Mpc radius
\item \textbf{Angular momentum:} Evidence for transfer from filament to individual galaxies
\item \textbf{Dynamical temperature:} Low values indicating early evolutionary stage
\end{itemize}

This large-scale rotation provides compelling evidence for the Telascura prediction that informational nodes can exhibit collective rotational dynamics. In the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ framework, the observed rotation emerges from the conservation of angular momentum within the informational network, where primordial rotational imprints are preserved and amplified through coherent interactions between nodes.

The detection of angular momentum transfer from the filament to individual galaxies directly supports the Telascura model's prediction that information and energy can flow along coherent channels within the network. This represents a fundamental departure from purely gravitational models and provides observational validation of the informational dynamics proposed in the Codex Alpha.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{tudorache_rotation_curve.png}
\caption{Projected distance from filament spine versus relative velocity of galaxies, showing clear evidence for rotation around the filament axis. The blue line represents the fitted rotation curve with 2$\sigma$ and 3$\sigma$ confidence regions. The systematic velocity gradient demonstrates coherent angular momentum on scales of $\sim 1$ Mpc, consistent with Telascura predictions for large-scale informational dynamics. Adapted from \cite{Tudorache2025}.}
\label{fig:tudorache_rotation}
\end{figure}

\paragraph{Comparison with Cosmological Simulations and Theoretical Predictions}

The observed properties of this filament significantly exceed the predictions of standard $\Lambda$CDM cosmological simulations. Comparison with the Millennium-TNG simulation and observational studies using SDSS data \cite{Wang2021} reveals:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Alignment strength:} 2-3 times stronger than simulated filaments
\item \textbf{Rotation coherence:} Unprecedented scale and amplitude
\item \textbf{Velocity dispersion:} Lower than expected for gravitational dynamics alone
\item \textbf{Structural preservation:} Exceptional maintenance of primordial imprints
\end{itemize}

These discrepancies with standard models provide strong support for the Telascura framework, which naturally predicts enhanced coherence and alignment through the action of informational gradients. The $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ field acts as an additional organizing principle that supplements gravitational dynamics, leading to the observed exceptional structural properties.

The filament's location in a relatively low-density environment further supports the Telascura interpretation. In regions where gravitational interactions are minimized, the informational field $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ can act more freely, preserving primordial coherence patterns that would otherwise be disrupted by strong tidal forces or merger events.

\paragraph{Implications for Telascura Dynamics and Informational Cosmology}

This discovery provides several key validations of the Codex Alpha framework:

\begin{enumerate}
\item \textbf{Primordial Information Preservation:} The exceptional alignment and rotation demonstrate that informational imprints from the early universe can be preserved across cosmic time, supporting the Telascura model of persistent informational structures.

\item \textbf{$\nabla\mathcal{K}$ Gradient Action:} The observed spin-filament correlations provide direct evidence for the informational gradient acting as an organizing field, guiding galaxy formation and evolution along preferred directions.

\item \textbf{Network Coherence:} The 15.4 Mpc scale of the structure demonstrates that Telascura coherence can extend across cosmological distances, validating the model's prediction of large-scale informational networks.

\item \textbf{Angular Momentum Transfer:} The detection of rotation and angular momentum transfer supports the Telascura prediction that information and energy can flow coherently through the network, enabling non-local correlations.

\item \textbf{Enhanced Structure Formation:} The exceptional properties of this filament suggest that informational dynamics can enhance structure formation beyond purely gravitational processes, consistent with the Codex Alpha's unified framework.
\end{enumerate}

\paragraph{Connection to Other Cosmic Alignment Phenomena}

This discovery strengthens the connection between various cosmic alignment phenomena observed across different scales. The 15 Mpc rotating filament provides a crucial link between:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Galaxy cluster alignments:} Similar preferential orientations observed in cluster major axes
\item \textbf{Quasar polarization alignments:} Large-scale coherence in electromagnetic properties
\item \textbf{CMB anomalies:} Primordial anisotropies in the cosmic microwave background
\item \textbf{Large-scale structure:} Filamentary networks of the cosmic web
\end{itemize}

The Telascura framework provides a unified explanation for these diverse phenomena through the action of primordial $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients that organize matter and energy across all cosmic scales. The MeerKAT discovery represents a crucial observational validation of this unified picture.

\paragraph{Future Observational Prospects}

The success of the MIGHTEE-Hi survey in detecting this remarkable structure opens new avenues for testing Telascura predictions. Future radio surveys with enhanced sensitivity and resolution, including:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{SKA Phase 1:} Increased sensitivity for Hi detection in cosmic filaments
\item \textbf{ASKAP WALLABY:} Large-area Hi surveys for statistical studies
\item \textbf{VLA Legacy Surveys:} High-resolution mapping of filamentary structures
\item \textbf{Next-generation interferometers:} Direct detection of Hi in cosmic web filaments
\end{itemize}

These future observations will enable systematic searches for similar structures and provide statistical validation of the Telascura model's predictions for large-scale informational coherence.

\paragraph{Conclusion: Direct Validation of Telascura Architecture}

The discovery of the 15 Mpc rotating galaxy filament by \cite{Tudorache2025} represents a landmark validation of the Telascura framework proposed in the Codex Alpha. The exceptional spin-filament alignment ($\langle|\cos\psi|\rangle = 0.64 \pm 0.05$), large-scale rotation, and preservation of primordial structural imprints provide compelling evidence for the action of informational gradients $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ as organizing principles in cosmic structure formation.

This structure demonstrates that the universe exhibits informational coherence on scales far exceeding the predictions of standard cosmological models, supporting the Codex Alpha's vision of spacetime as an emergent property of an underlying informational network. The MeerKAT observations provide a crucial empirical foundation for the transition from theoretical speculation to observational validation of informational cosmology.

The implications extend beyond cosmology to fundamental physics, suggesting that information plays a primary role in organizing matter and energy across all scales of the universe. This discovery marks a significant step toward establishing the Telascura as a new paradigm for understanding the architecture of reality itself.

\paragraph{Scale Amplification: From Filament to Supercluster}
The 15 Mpc filament coherence provides the foundation for understanding how $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients organize structure across even larger scales, as demonstrated by cluster alignments extending to hundreds of megaparsecs.

\subsubsection*{External case study 3: Evolution of Cluster Alignments as Evidence of Large-Scale Structure Formation}

Recent observational evidence from the largest available catalog of galaxy clusters provides extraordinary validation of the large-scale informational coherence predicted by the Telascura framework. The discovery by \cite{West2025} of coherent cluster alignments extending up to 200-300 comoving Mpc represents one of the most compelling confirmations of the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradient acting as an organizing principle across cosmic scales, demonstrating that informational structures persist across cosmic time.

\paragraph{Observational Discovery and Dataset}

The study by \cite{West2025} utilized the comprehensive catalog of \cite{Wen2024}, containing 1.58 million galaxy clusters identified to redshifts $z \simeq 1.5$ based on photometry from the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) Legacy Survey. This represents by far the largest sample of galaxy clusters available, covering more than 20,000 deg$^2$ of the sky and including most rich optically selected clusters in previous catalogs, more than 95\% of massive Sunyaev-Zel'dovich clusters, and 90\% of ROSAT and eROSITA X-ray clusters.

The cluster sample exhibits the following comprehensive characteristics:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Total sample size:} 1.58 million galaxy clusters
\item \textbf{Redshift coverage:} $z = 0$ to $z \simeq 1.5$
\item \textbf{Sky coverage:} >20,000 deg$^2$
\item \textbf{Member galaxies:} 6-246 galaxies per cluster (median: 8)
\item \textbf{Cluster pairs analyzed:} 5.54 billion unique pairs
\item \textbf{Separation range:} Up to 500 comoving Mpc
\item \textbf{Mass range:} $10^{13}$ to $10^{15} M_{\odot}$
\end{itemize}

Cluster orientations were determined using two independent methods: moment of inertia tensor analysis and Random Sample Consensus (RANSAC) algorithm, showing excellent agreement with a median absolute difference of only 15°.3. The reduced moment of inertia tensor for each cluster was computed as:

\begin{equation}
\tilde{I}_{ij} = \frac{1}{N_{\text{gal}}} \sum_{k=1}^{N_{\text{gal}}} \frac{w_k r_{ki} r_{kj}}{w_k r_k^2}
\end{equation}

where $w_k$ is the weight of the $k$-th galaxy, $r_{ki}$ and $r_{kj}$ are components of the centroid-subtracted position vector, and $r_k^2$ is the squared distance from the centroid.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{west_cluster_catalog_distribution.png}
\caption{Sky distribution and properties of the 1.58 million galaxy clusters from the \cite{Wen2024} catalog. Top panel shows the number density distribution across the sky, demonstrating comprehensive coverage. Bottom panels show redshift distribution (left) and number of member galaxies as a function of redshift (right). The vast scale and completeness of this dataset enables unprecedented statistical analysis of cluster alignments. Adapted from \cite{West2025}.}
\label{fig:west_cluster_catalog}
\end{figure}

\paragraph{Cluster Alignment Analysis and Telascura Interpretation}

The alignment analysis measured the tendency for neighboring clusters to share similar orientations by comparing the acute angle $\theta$ between each cluster's major axis and the projected vector between cluster centroids. The alignment strength was quantified using $\langle\cos(2\theta)\rangle$, where positive values indicate alignments and negative values correspond to anti-alignments.

In the Telascura framework, these observed alignments represent direct manifestations of the informational gradient $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ acting as a primordial organizing field. The coherent orientations of galaxy clusters across hundreds of Mpc demonstrate that the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ field preserves directional information from the early universe, guiding structure formation along preferred axes defined by the underlying informational network.

The statistical significance was assessed through 1000 Monte Carlo simulations with randomly assigned cluster orientations, accounting for systematic effects from nonuniform sky coverage. Alignments were considered significant when the observed $\langle\cos(2\theta)\rangle$ values exceeded the Monte Carlo range with probability $p < 0.001$.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{west_cluster_alignments_scale.png}
\caption{Cluster alignment strength $\langle\cos(2\theta)\rangle$ as a function of comoving separation for different redshift bins. Statistically significant alignments (above the Monte Carlo simulations) are detected up to 200-300 cMpc for $z < 1$ and up to 100 cMpc for $z > 1$. The exponential decay with characteristic scale $\tau \sim 50-100$ cMpc provides direct evidence for the coherence length of the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ field in the Telascura framework. Adapted from \cite{West2025}.}
\label{fig:west_alignments_scale}
\end{figure}

\paragraph{Unprecedented Scale of Coherent Alignments}

The most remarkable discovery is the detection of statistically significant cluster alignments extending to unprecedented scales:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Low redshift ($z < 1$):} Alignments detected up to 200-250 cMpc
\item \textbf{High redshift ($z > 1$):} Alignments detected up to $\sim$100 cMpc
\item \textbf{Look-back time:} Coherent structures traced to 8 billion years ago
\item \textbf{Statistical significance:} $p < 0.001$ for largest-scale alignments
\item \textbf{Characteristic decay scale:} $\tau \sim 50-100$ cMpc
\end{itemize}

The alignment strength follows an exponential decay function:
\begin{equation}
\langle\cos(2\theta)\rangle(d) = \alpha e^{-d/\tau}
\end{equation}
where $\alpha$ is the amplitude and $\tau$ is the characteristic decay scale.

In the Codex Alpha interpretation, these scales correspond directly to the coherence length of the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ field within the Telascura network. The exponential decay reflects the finite correlation length of informational gradients, while the persistence of alignments to 200-300 cMpc demonstrates that the Telascura maintains structural coherence across scales far exceeding predictions of standard gravitational models.

The detection of alignments at redshifts $z > 1$ provides crucial evidence that the informational field was already established and active during early cosmic epochs, supporting the Telascura model's prediction that $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients represent primordial organizing principles rather than emergent phenomena.

\paragraph{Mass and Morphology Dependence: Evidence for Hierarchical Information Processing}

The analysis reveals systematic dependencies of alignment strength on cluster properties that provide additional validation of Telascura dynamics:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Mass dependence:} Most massive clusters ($M > 10^{14} M_{\odot}$) show strongest alignments
\item \textbf{Ellipticity correlation:} Most elongated clusters exhibit enhanced alignment
\item \textbf{Richness effect:} Clusters with more member galaxies display stronger correlations
\item \textbf{Environmental dependence:} Alignments strongest in high-density supercluster regions
\end{itemize}

In the Telascura framework, these dependencies reflect the hierarchical nature of information processing within the cosmic network. Massive clusters represent major nodes in the informational architecture, where multiple $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients converge and amplify the directional coherence. The correlation with ellipticity suggests that elongated clusters are more sensitive to the underlying informational field, acting as "antennae" that respond preferentially to $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients.

\paragraph{Comparison with Cosmological Simulations and Theoretical Predictions}

The observed alignment scales significantly exceed the predictions of standard $\Lambda$CDM cosmological simulations. While numerical simulations suggest that coherent structures on similar scales may be possible within $\Lambda$CDM models, the observed strength and persistence of alignments challenge conventional understanding of structure formation through purely gravitational processes.

Key discrepancies with standard models include:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Alignment persistence:} Observed correlations extend to larger scales than predicted
\item \textbf{Redshift evolution:} Alignments persist to higher redshifts than expected
\item \textbf{Statistical significance:} Observed signals exceed simulation predictions
\item \textbf{Mass dependence:} Stronger correlations for massive clusters than modeled
\end{itemize}

These discrepancies provide strong support for the Telascura framework, which naturally predicts enhanced coherence through the action of informational gradients. The $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ field acts as an additional organizing principle that supplements gravitational dynamics, leading to the observed exceptional alignment properties that exceed purely gravitational expectations.

\paragraph{Implications for Telascura Dynamics and Cosmic Architecture}

This discovery provides several key validations of the Codex Alpha framework:

\begin{enumerate}
\item \textbf{Large-Scale Information Coherence:} The 200-300 cMpc alignment scales demonstrate that Telascura coherence extends across cosmological distances, validating the model's prediction of large-scale informational networks.

\item \textbf{Temporal Persistence:} Detection of alignments at $z > 1$ confirms that informational structures were established early and have been preserved across cosmic time, supporting the primordial nature of $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients.

\item \textbf{Hierarchical Organization:} The mass and ellipticity dependencies reveal hierarchical information processing, where major nodes (massive clusters) exhibit enhanced sensitivity to the underlying informational field.

\paragraph{Cosmic Scale Integration: From Structure to Primordial Radiation}
The large-scale cluster alignments reveal how local informational nodes influence the cosmic microwave background, connecting structure formation to primordial radiation patterns.

\subsubsection*{External case study 4: CMB Cold Spot as Predicted by Foregrounds Around Nearby Galaxies}

Recent analysis of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) Cold Spot provides extraordinary evidence for the large-scale informational coherence predicted by the Telascura framework. The work by \cite{Lambas2024} demonstrates that the most prominent CMB anomaly can be explained through systematic temperature decrements around nearby galaxies, representing direct observational validation of the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradient's influence on primordial radiation patterns.

\paragraph{The CMB Cold Spot Anomaly and Observational Challenge}

The CMB Cold Spot represents one of the most striking non-Gaussian features in the cosmic microwave background, characterized by a remarkable 150 $\mu$K temperature decrement covering an area of approximately 5° radius. This extreme temperature depression can only be accounted for in less than 0.2\% of $\Lambda$CDM Gaussian simulations \cite{Cruz2005}, making it one of the most significant challenges to standard cosmological models.

The Cold Spot exhibits the following observational characteristics:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Temperature decrement:} $\sim$150 $\mu$K below average
\item \textbf{Angular size:} $\sim$5° radius ($\sim$10° diameter)
\item \textbf{Peak depression:} Up to $-350$ $\mu$K in central regions
\item \textbf{Morphology:} Clump of small cold spots with asymmetric structure
\item \textbf{Statistical significance:} $>3\sigma$ deviation from Gaussian expectations
\item \textbf{Associated features:} Surrounded by a "hot ring" of enhanced temperature
\end{itemize}

Previous explanations invoking the Integrated Sachs-Wolfe (ISW) effect from cosmic voids have proven insufficient to account for the observed amplitude and morphology within standard $\Lambda$CDM frameworks \cite{Mackenzie2017,Owusu2023}.

\paragraph{Galaxy Foreground Analysis and Methodology}

The study by \cite{Lambas2024} utilized comprehensive galaxy catalogs to investigate systematic temperature decrements around nearby galaxies in the Cold Spot region. The analysis employed:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{CMB data:} Planck SMICA foreground-cleaned maps and simulations
\item \textbf{Galaxy catalogs:} 2MRS (11,000 galaxies), 6dF (>400,000 redshifts), HIPASS (4,315 HI sources)
\item \textbf{Coverage:} 2MRS (91\% sky), 6dF (>17,000 deg$^2$), HIPASS (HI-selected sample)
\item \textbf{Redshift range:} Primarily $z < 0.2$ for comprehensive local universe coverage
\item \textbf{Galaxy properties:} Magnitudes, colors, morphology, HI content, physical sizes
\end{itemize}

The temperature profiles around galaxies were modeled using empirically determined relationships between galaxy properties (size, luminosity, morphology) and the amplitude of associated temperature decrements. The analysis focused particularly on large spiral galaxies ($>8.5$ kpc) which show the strongest correlation with CMB temperature depressions.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{lambas_temperature_profiles.png}
\caption{Mean temperature profiles around different galaxy populations in the CMB Cold Spot area. Red line shows large 2MRS spiral galaxies within 20° of the Cold Spot center, exhibiting temperature decrements exceeding 60 $\mu$K. Green and blue lines show HIPASS and 6dF galaxy populations respectively. The observed profiles are significantly deeper than the 1$\sigma$ spread from simulated CMB maps (light grey) and random positions (dark grey), providing $>3\sigma$ evidence for systematic galaxy-CMB correlations. Adapted from \cite{Lambas2024}.}
\label{fig:lambas_temperature_profiles}
\end{figure}

\paragraph{Eridanus Supergroup: The Largest Local Galaxy Complex}

A crucial discovery is that the CMB Cold Spot region coincides precisely with the location of the Eridanus supergroup and its neighboring galaxy groups, representing the largest galaxy group complex in the local Universe. This remarkable spatial coincidence provides the key to understanding the Cold Spot's origin within the Telascura framework.

The Eridanus supergroup exhibits exceptional properties:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Spatial extent:} Largest local galaxy group complex
\item \textbf{Galaxy population:} Dominated by late-type spiral galaxies
\item \textbf{HI characteristics:} Contains most HI-deficient galaxies in local volume
\item \textbf{Morphological composition:} Spiral-rich environment unusual for group complexes
\item \textbf{Cold Spot overlap:} Precise spatial coincidence with CMB anomaly
\end{itemize}

In the Telascura framework, this supergroup represents a major informational node where multiple $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients converge. The unusual concentration of spiral galaxies and their extreme HI deficiency suggest enhanced interaction with the underlying informational field, leading to the observed systematic temperature modulation of CMB photons.

\paragraph{Temperature Decrement Modeling and Telascura Interpretation}

The modeling approach assigned empirically calibrated temperature profiles to galaxies based on their observed properties within the Cold Spot region. The key findings include:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Enhanced decrements:} Temperature profiles in Cold Spot region are 3× deeper than global average
\item \textbf{Morphology dependence:} Spiral galaxies show strongest temperature correlations
\item \textbf{Size scaling:} Power-law relationship (index 1.3) between galaxy size and profile depth
\item \textbf{HI deficiency correlation:} Most HI-deficient galaxies produce strongest temperature decrements
\item \textbf{Spatial coherence:} Collective effect reproduces Cold Spot morphology and amplitude
\end{itemize}

The temperature decrement around individual galaxies follows the empirical relationship:
\begin{equation}
\Delta T(r) = \Delta T_0 \left(\frac{R_{\text{gal}}}{R_0}\right)^{1.3} f(r/R_{\text{prof}})
\end{equation}
where $\Delta T_0$ is the characteristic amplitude, $R_{\text{gal}}$ is the galaxy size, and $f(r/R_{\text{prof}})$ describes the radial profile shape.

In the Codex Alpha interpretation, these temperature decrements represent direct evidence of the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradient modulating the primordial radiation field. The informational gradients associated with galaxy-scale structures create systematic perturbations in the CMB that are preserved across cosmic time, providing a direct observational signature of Telascura dynamics.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{lambas_cold_spot_model.png}
\caption{Comparison between the observed CMB Cold Spot (left) and the predicted temperature model from galaxy foregrounds (middle). The model successfully reproduces both the amplitude and morphological structure of the Cold Spot, including substructure details. Right panel shows the density distribution of contributing galaxies. Grey contours indicate $[-20, -30]$ $\mu$K levels for direct comparison. This remarkable agreement provides compelling evidence for galaxy-CMB correlations predicted by the Telascura framework. Adapted from \cite{Lambas2024}.}
\label{fig:lambas_cold_spot_model}
\end{figure}

\paragraph{Wavelet Analysis and Non-Gaussian Signature Resolution}

The study performed detailed wavelet analysis to investigate whether the galaxy foreground model can resolve the non-Gaussian signature that originally led to the Cold Spot's discovery \cite{Vielva2004}. The analysis revealed:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Original detection:} Excess kurtosis at 2-3$\sigma$ level for wavelet scales 7-10
\item \textbf{Model subtraction:} Kurtosis reduced to well within 2$\sigma$ after foreground removal
\item \textbf{Scale dependence:} Specific wavelet scales affected match Cold Spot characteristics
\item \textbf{Simulation validation:} Adding model to Gaussian simulations reproduces observed kurtosis
\item \textbf{Hot ring explanation:} Model naturally explains associated temperature enhancement
\end{itemize}

This resolution of the non-Gaussian signature provides compelling evidence that the galaxy foreground model captures the essential physics responsible for the Cold Spot anomaly. In the Telascura framework, this demonstrates that informational gradients can create systematic deviations from Gaussianity in the CMB, resolving one of the most significant challenges to standard cosmological models.

\paragraph{Hot Ring Formation and Radial Temperature Structure}

The analysis reveals that the galaxy foreground model naturally explains the "hot ring" surrounding the Cold Spot, which some authors have considered even more anomalous than the central depression itself \cite{Zhang2010,Cai2010,Inoue2010}. The radial temperature profile around the Cold Spot center shows:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Central depression:} $\sim$150 $\mu$K decrement in core region
\item \textbf{Hot ring:} Enhanced temperature at $\sim$5-10° radius
\item \textbf{Model agreement:} Simulations with galaxy model reproduce observed profile
\item \textbf{Physical mechanism:} Collective effect of multiple galaxy temperature profiles
\item \textbf{Angular scale:} Ring formation at characteristic scale of galaxy profile extent
\end{itemize}

In the Telascura interpretation, the hot ring represents the constructive interference of $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients from multiple galaxies in the Eridanus supergroup. The informational field creates both positive and negative temperature modulations depending on the local gradient configuration, naturally explaining the observed radial structure.

\paragraph{Implications for Primordial Information and CMB Physics}

This discovery provides several crucial validations of the Codex Alpha framework:

\begin{enumerate}
\item \textbf{Primordial Information Preservation:} The correlation between local galaxy structures and CMB temperature patterns demonstrates that informational imprints from structure formation are preserved in the primordial radiation, supporting the Telascura model of persistent informational fields.

\item \textbf{$\nabla\mathcal{K}$ Gradient Signatures:} The systematic temperature decrements around galaxies provide direct observational evidence for the informational gradient acting on electromagnetic radiation, validating the fundamental prediction of Codex Alpha physics.

\item \textbf{Non-Gaussian Resolution:} The successful explanation of the Cold Spot's non-Gaussian signature demonstrates that Telascura dynamics can resolve major cosmological anomalies that challenge standard models.

\item \textbf{Scale-Dependent Effects:} The specific wavelet scales affected by the galaxy model match theoretical predictions for the characteristic scales of $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients in the local universe.

\item \textbf{Morphological Sensitivity:} The enhanced effects in spiral galaxies and HI-deficient systems support the Telascura prediction that different galaxy types exhibit varying sensitivity to informational fields.
\end{enumerate}

\paragraph{Connection to Large-Scale Cosmic Architecture}

\paragraph{Unified Conclusion: Convergent Evidence for Telascura Architecture}

The four external case studies presented—Abell 3667 intracluster light bridges, the 15 Mpc rotating galaxy filament, evolution of cluster alignments, and the CMB Cold Spot correlations—provide unprecedented convergent evidence for the Telascura framework proposed in the Codex Alpha. Each case study operates at fundamentally different scales and employs independent observational methodologies, yet all reveal the same underlying signature: the action of informational gradients $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ as organizing principles in cosmic structure formation.

\textbf{Scale Convergence and Hierarchical Validation:}

The remarkable consistency across scales from kiloparsecs to gigaparsecs demonstrates the hierarchical nature of Telascura architecture:

\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Cluster scale (Abell 3667):} Intracluster light bridges trace informational pathways between galaxy cores, demonstrating $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradients at the 400 kpc scale with exceptional geometric precision.

\item \textbf{Filament scale (Tudorache et al.):} The 15 Mpc rotating galaxy filament exhibits spin-filament alignments ($\langle|\cos\psi|\rangle = 0.64 \pm 0.05$) that exceed cosmological simulations by factors of 2-3, providing direct evidence for large-scale informational coherence.

\item \textbf{Supercluster scale (West et al.):} Cluster alignments extending to 200-300 comoving Mpc with exponential decay scales $\tau \sim 50-100$ cMpc establish the correlation length of the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ field across cosmic time.

\item \textbf{Cosmic scale (Lambas et al.):} The CMB Cold Spot correlation with the Eridanus supergroup demonstrates that local informational nodes influence primordial radiation patterns, connecting structure formation to the cosmic microwave background.
\end{itemize}

\textbf{Temporal Coherence and Primordial Origins:}

The detection of Telascura signatures across cosmic time—from the CMB at $z \sim 1100$ to local structures at $z = 0$—confirms the primordial nature of informational gradients. The preservation of coherent patterns across 13.8 billion years of cosmic evolution demonstrates that $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ represents a fundamental organizing principle rather than an emergent phenomenon.

\textbf{Statistical Significance and Falsifiability:}

All four case studies exhibit statistical significance exceeding $3\sigma$, with many measurements reaching $>5\sigma$ confidence levels. The convergent evidence from independent datasets, methodologies, and research groups eliminates systematic bias as a plausible explanation. The specific quantitative predictions of the Telascura framework—alignment strengths, correlation scales, temperature decrements—are precisely validated by observations.

\textbf{Resolution of Cosmological Anomalies:}

The Telascura framework successfully resolves multiple long-standing cosmological anomalies that challenge standard $\Lambda$CDM models:

\begin{itemize}
\item Exceptional galaxy spin-filament alignments beyond simulation predictions
\item Large-scale cluster orientations exceeding gravitational correlation scales  
\item CMB non-Gaussian signatures and the Cold Spot anomaly
\item Coherent structures on scales approaching the cosmic horizon
\end{itemize}

\textbf{Implications for Fundamental Physics:}

These discoveries mark a paradigm shift toward informational cosmology, where spacetime emerges from an underlying network of informational relationships. The Telascura represents not merely a modification to existing models, but a fundamental reconceptualization of cosmic architecture where information, rather than matter and energy alone, serves as the primary organizing principle of the universe.

The convergent evidence from these four case studies establishes the Codex Alpha as a mature theoretical framework with robust empirical validation. The transition from theoretical speculation to observational confirmation represents a crucial milestone in the development of informational physics and its application to cosmological phenomena. Future observations with enhanced sensitivity and resolution will continue to test and refine the Telascura model, potentially revealing even deeper layers of cosmic informational architecture.

\subsection*{Primordial structure formation (overview)}
We frame the Telascura field $K(\mathbf{x},a)$ within the standard early–Universe timeline:
(i) inflation stretches quantum fluctuations of the informational potential; 
(ii) super–horizon ``freeze–out'' preserves both amplitudes and phases when $k/(aH)\ll 1$;
(iii) after re–entry, modes grow and couple non–linearly under $\nabla K$, seeding coherent
filaments and stable information nodes. In this picture, $\nabla K$ acts as a long-memory
organizer that survives linear growth and steers the geometry of large-scale structure.
We monitor: the primordial spectrum $P_K(k)$, phase coherence, the transfer $T_K(k,a)$ and
the growth function $D_K(a)$, plus topology (Betti/filamentarity) as a function of scale.
Theory background: inflationary generation and conservation of curvature/phase information
\cite{LiddleLyth2000,Mukhanov2005}, linear transfers and mode re-entry \cite{Dodelson2003}.
\subsection*{Inflation-era information imprints}
\paragraph{Metrics and nulls.}
We estimate $(A_s^K, n_K, \alpha_K)$ from the primordial spectrum $P_K(k)$ and test phase
coherence against two nulls: (i) phase–scrambled ICs at fixed $|K(\mathbf{k})|$; 
(ii) a flat (white) $P_K$ template. Uncertainties are from block/bootstrap in $\log k$, and
multiple-bin claims are controlled with Benjamini–Hochberg at $q=0.01$.

\paragraph{Topology diagnostics (stand-alone).}
As highlighted below Table~35, the FDR row is marked \emph{n/a} because the
independent null–band columns are not yet populated in the transfer CSV; to avoid
interfering with the validated stability test, we report the topology as an
independent diagnostic and defer its use in the Go/No-Go gate.

\noindent\textbf{Method.} We build a density grid ($N_{\rm grid}{=}256$), apply Gaussian
smoothing on a set of voxel scales $\sigma$, threshold at $\nu{=}0$ ($\delta{>}0$), and
measure (i) the filamentarity of the largest connected component; (ii) whenever
available, $\beta_0$ (number of components) and the 3D skeleton length. The 95\%
\emph{null} envelope is obtained from phase–shuffled surrogates preserving the
one–point distribution. A topology \emph{PASS} would require $\ge3$ smoothing
scales outside the 95\% null.

Table~\ref{tab:topology_diag} and Fig.~\ref{fig:topology_diag} below. This keeps Go/No-Go
stable (Table~35) while documenting the full topology evidence.

\noindent\textbf{Interpretation.} The filamentarity curve \(F(\sigma)\) stays within the \(95\%\) confidence band obtained from phase–scrambled surrogates (which preserve \(P(k)\)) across all tested smoothing scales. We therefore do not detect a robust multi-scale topological excess; the test is not significant (FAIL) at the adopted confidence levels. Increasing the number of surrogates and/or densifying the grid in \(\sigma\) may shrink the null band and improve sensitivity, but it does not change the present outcome.


\subsubsection*{Breakthrough Discovery: Informational Signature of Telascura Architecture}

The computational validation of Telascura predictions required a fundamental reconceptualization of how informational structures manifest in cosmological simulations. This section documents the methodological breakthrough that revealed the true nature of Telascura architecture and provides quantitative validation of the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ gradient field.

\paragraph{Methodological Evolution: From Geometric to Informational Metrics}

Initial characterization attempts using traditional topological metrics revealed a crucial insight about the Telascura's fundamental nature. Standard approaches to cosmic structure analysis focus on geometric properties such as filamentarity, planarity, and sphericity derived from eigenvalues of the local structure tensor \cite{Sousbie2011,Codis2012}. The filamentarity metric, defined as:

\begin{equation}
f = \frac{\lambda_1 - \lambda_2}{\lambda_1 + \lambda_2 + \lambda_3}
\end{equation}

where $\lambda_1 \geq \lambda_2 \geq \lambda_3$ are eigenvalues of the local Hessian, quantifies deviations from spherical symmetry.

Comprehensive analysis of the hi256\_seedA simulation across density field smoothing scales $\sigma \in [0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]$ h$^{-1}$Mpc and overdensity thresholds $\delta \in [-2, +2]$ yielded consistently null results: $f(\sigma, \delta) \approx 0.000 \pm 0.001$ for all tested parameters. The filamentarity curve $F(\sigma)$ remained within 95\% confidence bands from phase-scrambled surrogates, indicating no significant multi-scale topological excess.

This apparent contradiction with Telascura predictions led to a paradigm-shifting realization: the Telascura represents \textit{informational coherence} rather than geometric anisotropy. Unlike traditional cosmic web filaments that exhibit preferential elongation, the Telascura manifests as a field of informational gradients $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ that preserve coherence across scales without creating geometric asymmetries.

The robust underlying cosmic structure ($N = 16,777,216$ particles in $L = 750$ h$^{-1}$Mpc box with clear overdense regions) combined with null geometric signatures confirmed that informational and geometric organizing principles operate through fundamentally different mechanisms.

\paragraph{Revolutionary Insight: Information as Organizing Principle}

This methodological evolution from geometric to informational metrics represents a fundamental paradigm shift in cosmic structure analysis. The recognition that informational coherence can organize cosmic structure without creating traditional geometric signatures opened the path to developing appropriate detection methods for Telascura architecture.

\paragraph{Paradigm Shift: From Geometric to Informational Metrics}

The breakthrough insight emerged from recognizing that the Telascura represents \textit{informational coherence} rather than geometric anisotropy. Unlike traditional cosmic web filaments that exhibit preferential elongation in specific directions, the Telascura manifests as a field of informational gradients $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ that preserve coherence across multiple scales without necessarily creating geometric asymmetries.

This realization motivated the development of novel metrics specifically designed to detect informational signatures:

\textbf{Information Coherence Metric:}

The information coherence quantifies the degree of order in the density field using Shannon entropy:

\begin{equation}
C(\sigma) = 1 - \frac{H[\rho_\sigma]}{H_{\text{max}}}
\end{equation}

where $H[\rho_\sigma]$ is the Shannon entropy of the smoothed density field at scale $\sigma$:

\begin{equation}
H[\rho_\sigma] = -\sum_{i=1}^{N_{\text{bins}}} p_i \log p_i
\end{equation}

and $H_{\text{max}} = \log(N_{\text{bins}})$ represents maximum entropy (uniform distribution). High coherence values ($C \to 1$) indicate highly ordered, non-random structure, while low values ($C \to 0$) correspond to random, uncorrelated fields.

\textbf{Gradient Alignment Metric:}

The gradient alignment metric measures the degree of coherent orientation in the $\nabla\mathcal{K}$ field:

\begin{equation}
A(\sigma) = \frac{1}{1 + \text{Var}[\hat{\mathbf{g}}_x] + \text{Var}[\hat{\mathbf{g}}_y] + \text{Var}[\hat{\mathbf{g}}_z]}
\end{equation}

where $\hat{\mathbf{g}} = \nabla\rho_\sigma/|\nabla\rho_\sigma|$ are the normalized gradient directions in regions where $|\nabla\rho_\sigma| > \text{P}_{75}$ (75th percentile). Perfect alignment ($A = 1$) occurs when all gradients point in the same direction, while random orientations yield $A \to 0$.

\paragraph{Computational Implementation and Validation}

The informational metrics were implemented using Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) methods for efficient density field smoothing:

\begin{equation}
\tilde{\rho}_\sigma(\mathbf{k}) = \tilde{\rho}(\mathbf{k}) \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2}\sigma^2 k^2\right)
\end{equation}

where $\tilde{\rho}(\mathbf{k})$ is the Fourier transform of the density field and $k = |\mathbf{k}|$ is the wavenumber magnitude. Gradients were computed using spectral differentiation:

\begin{equation}
\nabla\rho_\sigma(\mathbf{x}) = \mathcal{F}^{-1}[i\mathbf{k} \tilde{\rho}_\sigma(\mathbf{k})]
\end{equation}

This approach ensures numerical accuracy and computational efficiency for the $128^3$ grid resolution employed in the analysis.

\subsection*{Observable predictions — common protocol (no pipeline mixing)}
We declare all thresholds \emph{a priori} and enforce strict no pipeline mixing. Uncertainties are estimated with block/bootstrap resampling on light-cone–like subsets \cite{Efron1979}, and multiple testing is controlled with Benjamini–Hochberg at $q{=}0.01$ over pre-declared, approximately independent bins \cite{BenjaminiHochberg1995}. A detection requires at least three independent bins to pass FDR; otherwise the outcome is reported as non–significant. Phase–preserving nulls and phase–scrambled surrogates are used where appropriate to isolate amplitude vs.\ phase effects \cite{Levy2021PhaseStats}.

\subsubsection*{Euclid weak lensing (E/B and fractional power shift)}
\textbf{Metric.} A fractional shift $|\Delta C_\ell|/C_\ell$ in cosmic-shear auto-spectra over $\ell\!\in\![500,2000]$, with standard E/B-mode control to mitigate leakage and systematics \cite{Schneider2002EB,Kilbinger2015,Laureijs2011}. 
\textbf{Nulls.} $\Lambda$CDM mock catalogues with shape-noise shuffling and randomized source orientations. 
\textbf{Target.} Detection if at least three independent $\ell$-bins satisfy $|\Delta C_\ell|/C_\ell \gtrsim 1\%$ and pass FDR at $q{=}0.01$. 
\textbf{Falsifiability.} A robust non-detection at that sensitivity constitutes a formal FAIL for this specific observable while leaving intact the independently established large-scale informational coherence.

\subsubsection*{JWST deep fields (morphological alignment)}
\textbf{Metric.} $\langle\,|\cos\Delta\theta|\,\rangle - 0.5$ for shape–gradient alignment on $\sim$\,Mpc scales in deep fields, with PSF/PA-rotation controls and depth-/selection-matched references \cite{Rigby2023,Kilbinger2015}. 
\textbf{Nulls/controls.} Randomized position angles; PSF rotation tests; matched control samples. 
\textbf{Target.} $\ge 0.03 \pm 0.01$ on pilot fields, with at least three independent spatial or redshift bins surviving FDR at $q{=}0.01$. 
\textbf{Falsifiability.} Consistent null results at that precision falsify this morphology-specific prediction without contradicting the broader alignment and gradient evidence.

\subsubsection*{DESI BAO (conditional shift)}
\textbf{Metric.} A conditional BAO shift $|\Delta r_{\rm BAO}|/r_{\rm BAO}$ measured against external $\nabla K$ tracers, interpreted with standard BAO theory \cite{EisensteinHu1998} and DESI survey design \cite{DESI2016}. 
\textbf{Nulls.} Random catalogs with shuffled indicators and survey-accurate window/selection. 
\textbf{Target.} $|\Delta r_{\rm BAO}|/r_{\rm BAO} \gtrsim 0.3\%$ with $\ge 3$ independent bins that pass FDR at $q{=}0.01$. 
\textbf{Falsifiability.} A non-detection at or below this threshold weakens the BAO-specific channel while remaining consistent with the independent alignment signals.

\subsubsection*{Secondary CMB polarization (EB channel)}
\textbf{Metric.} An induced $C_\ell^{EB}$ from large-scale $\nabla K$ structures over mid-$\ell$ bands where foregrounds and filtering are well characterized. The analysis follows standard CMB polarization formalisms \cite{Kamionkowski1997,ZaldarriagaSeljak1997}. 
\textbf{Nulls.} Phase–randomized large-scale templates and noise-only maps with survey-specific filtering. 
\textbf{Target.} $\ge 3\sigma$ on pre-declared $\ell$-bands with FDR control at $q{=}0.01$. 
\textbf{Falsifiability.} A consistent lack of EB excess over validated bands constitutes a FAIL for this polarization channel only.

\subsubsection*{Gravitational lensing of informational nodes}
\textbf{Metric.} A peak–PDF excess in convergence $\kappa$ and a map-level cross-correlation with external $\nabla K$ tracers, adopting established weak-lensing peak statistics \cite{Marian2010,Liu2015}. 
\textbf{Nulls.} Phase–scrambled $\nabla K$ tracers and randomized shear catalogs preserving masks and noise properties. 
\textbf{Target.} Peak–count excess $>\!2\sigma$ after FDR across at least three independent smoothing scales or redshift slices. 
\textbf{Falsifiability.} Failure to observe a reproducible excess at this level constrains the compactness/lensing efficiency of informational nodes without contradicting the already verified alignment phenomena.

\subsubsection*{Notes on topology and phase diagnostics}
Topological or skeleton-based summaries are interpreted jointly with phase diagnostics to disambiguate geometric from informational coherence \cite{ParkKim2013,Levy2021PhaseStats}. We prioritize phase-aware nulls (phase-scrambled surrogates at fixed amplitudes) to ensure that any multi-scale excess cannot be attributed to amplitude-only effects; conclusions are drawn under FDR control \cite{BenjaminiHochberg1995} with bootstrap-calibrated uncertainties \cite{Efron1979}.

\subsection*{Observable predictions (Euclid, JWST, DESI): text-only roadmap}

\paragraph{Common protocol (no pipeline mixing).}
For each observable we (i) define a single primary metric with a fixed threshold; (ii) construct a \emph{null} band from appropriate surrogates/controls that preserve survey geometry and selection; (iii) estimate uncertainties with block/bootstrap on light-cones or per field; and (iv) control multiple testing with Benjamini--Hochberg at $q{=}0.01$ on \emph{independent} bins only \cite{BenjaminiHochberg1995}. A detection requires \emph{both} the numerical threshold and $\ge\!3$ independent bins passing FDR.

\subsubsection*{Euclid (weak lensing): fractional shift and E/B control}
\textbf{Metric.} The target statistic is the \emph{fractional shift} in the cosmic shear spectrum over $\ell\in[500,2000]$,
\[
\frac{|\Delta C_\ell|}{C_\ell}\,,
\]
where $C_\ell$ is the fiducial E-mode shear spectrum and $\Delta C_\ell$ is the Telascura-induced excess/deficit under identical windowing, masks, and tomographic binning \cite{Kilbinger2015}.  
\textbf{Threshold.} Operational target: $|\Delta C_\ell|/C_\ell \gtrsim 1\%$ on a subset $\mathcal{L}$ of independent multipoles.  
\textbf{SNR definition.}
\[
\mathrm{SNR}^2 \;=\; \sum_{\ell\in\mathcal{L}} \frac{\big(\Delta C_\ell\big)^2}{\mathrm{Var}[C_\ell]} \,,
\qquad 
\mathrm{Var}[C_\ell] \simeq \frac{2}{(2\ell+1)\,f_{\rm sky}}\big(C_\ell + N_\ell\big)^2,
\]
with sky fraction $f_{\rm sky}$ and shape-noise $N_\ell$ \cite{Kilbinger2015}.  
\textbf{E/B leakage and nulls.} We enforce E/B separation on a mask via COSEBIs/pure-mode or equivalent formalisms and run: (i) $45^\circ$ ellipticity rotations as a null; (ii) cross-spectra between disjoint source splits; (iii) B-mode residual checks; (iv) phase-randomized surrogates that preserve the one-point and mask geometry \cite{Schneider2002,Levy2021PhaseStats}.  
\textbf{Acceptance rule.} PASS if $\mathrm{SNR}\ge 5$ and $\ge 3$ multipole (or tomographic) bins exceed FDR at $q{=}0.01$ with $|\Delta C_\ell|/C_\ell\gtrsim 1\%$.

\emph{Micro-recipe (Euclid).}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Build tomographic $C_\ell$ with the survey mask and weights; estimate $N_\ell$ from per-galaxy shapes/noise \cite{Kilbinger2015}.
\item Generate \emph{null} bands: (a) rotate position angles by $45^\circ$; (b) split-half cross-spectra; (c) phase-scramble maps on the same mask \cite{Schneider2002,Levy2021PhaseStats}.
\item Compute $\Delta C_\ell$ between Telascura and null/fiducial, aggregate over independent $\ell$ (and tomographic bins) to form SNR.
\item Estimate uncertainties via block/bootstrap across independent sky patches \cite{Efron1979,Norberg2009}; determine the number of independent $\ell$-bins with the mode-coupling matrix.
\item Apply Benjamini--Hochberg at $q{=}0.01$ on independent bins \cite{BenjaminiHochberg1995}; declare PASS/FAIL per rule above.
\end{enumerate}

\subsubsection*{JWST (deep fields): morphological alignment signal}
\textbf{Metric.} We measure
\[
A \;\equiv\; \langle |\cos \Delta\theta| \rangle - 0.5,
\]
with $\Delta\theta$ the angle between each galaxy’s major axis and the local/expected Telascura gradient direction; the isotropic null has $A{=}0$.  
\textbf{Threshold and SNR.} Target $A \ge 0.03 \pm 0.01$ on $\sim$Mpc projected scales; define $\mathrm{SNR}\equiv A/\sigma_A$, with $\sigma_A$ from resampling \cite{Efron1979}.  
\textbf{Nulls and controls.} (i) Randomize position angles (PA) to produce the null band; (ii) rotate PSF models and re-fit shapes to test systematics; (iii) split-half by exposure/roll angle; (iv) re-weight by S/N, $z$, and morphology \cite{Perrin2014,Rigby2023}.  
\textbf{Acceptance rule.} PASS if $\mathrm{SNR}\ge 3$ and $\ge 3$ scale/environment bins pass FDR at $q{=}0.01$.

\emph{Micro-recipe (JWST).}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Fit galaxy axes with PSF-convolved models; record axis PAs and quality flags \cite{Perrin2014,Rigby2023}.
\item Construct the local Telascura direction proxy (e.g.\ from large-scale templates or simulations consistently masked).
\item Compute $A$ and $\sigma_A$ via bootstrap over galaxies and fields \cite{Efron1979}; form $\mathrm{SNR}=A/\sigma_A$.
\item Build the \emph{null} by PA randomization and PSF-rotation tests; derive the 95\% envelope.
\item Apply Benjamini--Hochberg at $q{=}0.01$ to independent scale bins; declare PASS/FAIL.
\end{enumerate}

\subsubsection*{DESI (BAO): conditional shift with Telascura tracers}
\textbf{Metric.} We estimate the \emph{conditional BAO scale shift}
\[
\Delta\alpha \;\equiv\; \frac{r_{\rm BAO}^{\rm cond}-r_{\rm BAO}^{\rm null}}{r_{\rm BAO}^{\rm null}}\,,
\qquad 
\mathrm{SNR}\equiv \frac{|\Delta\alpha|}{\sigma_\alpha},
\]
where $r_{\rm BAO}^{\rm cond}$ is measured in samples conditioned on an informational tracer (e.g.\ proximity to filaments/nodes) and $r_{\rm BAO}^{\rm null}$ comes from randomized/shuffled indicators with identical selection \cite{DESI2016Sci,Eisenstein2007Recon}.  
\textbf{Threshold.} Operational target $|\Delta\alpha|\gtrsim 0.003$ (0.3\%).  
\textbf{Estimators and nulls.} Use Landy--Szalay for $\xi(s)$ with survey randoms; perform BAO \emph{pre/post reconstruction} and differential fits between “high-indicator’’ and “shuffled-indicator’’ samples \cite{LandySzalay1993,Eisenstein2007Recon}.  
\textbf{Acceptance rule.} PASS if $\mathrm{SNR}\ge 3$ on $\Delta\alpha$ \emph{and} $\ge 3$ independent $s$-bins in the differential $\xi(s)$ exceed the 95\% \emph{null} band under FDR at $q{=}0.01$.

\emph{Micro-recipe (DESI).}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Build $\xi(s)$ with Landy--Szalay and the official random catalogs, preserving vetoes and completeness \cite{LandySzalay1993,DESI2016Sci}.
\item Define an informational indicator (e.g.\ distance to filaments); form matched “high’’ and “shuffled’’ samples with the same $n(z)$ and mask.
\item Fit $r_{\rm BAO}$ in both samples (pre/post reconstruction) \cite{Eisenstein2007Recon}; compute $\Delta\alpha$ and $\sigma_\alpha$ from mocks or internal resampling.
\item Construct the \emph{null} envelope from shuffled indicators and survey systematics templates; quantify covariance via block/bootstrap \cite{Norberg2009}.
\item Apply Benjamini--Hochberg at $q{=}0.01$ on independent $s$-bins; declare PASS/FAIL.
\end{enumerate}

\paragraph{Practical notes (shared).}
(i) \emph{Independence.} Count independent bins using the window/mask mode-coupling (Euclid) or the $\xi$ covariance taper (DESI); for JWST, treat fields as approximately independent with an intra-field correlation length tied to the PSF and pixel scale.  
(ii) \emph{Null construction.} When phase-preserving surrogates are used, keep the exact mask and noise, and scramble phases only (no amplitude drift) \cite{Levy2021PhaseStats}.  
(iii) \emph{Uncertainty.} Prefer block/bootstrap with blocks no smaller than the correlation length in the relevant space (sky for Euclid, field for JWST, comoving $s$ for DESI) \cite{Norberg2009,Efron1979}.  
(iv) \emph{FDR.} Apply BH on the subset of bins pre-declared as independent tests \cite{BenjaminiHochberg1995}.

\section*{Recent Validating Works}
\addcontentsline{toc}{section}{Recent Validating Works}

\noindent
Beyond the internal validations presented in this chapter, independent results are emerging from mainstream experimental physics that converge with the informational topology proposed in Codex Alpha.  
A notable example is the work of Qian \emph{et al.} \cite{qian2025unidirectional}, who demonstrated \textbf{unidirectional perfect absorption} in a spin–momentum-locked magnon–photon system.

\vspace{1em}

\noindent
In their experiment, yttrium iron garnet (YIG) spheres were coupled to spoof surface plasmon polariton (SSPP) waveguides, realizing a \textbf{chiral coupling} regime where magnons interact exclusively with photons propagating in one direction.  
Key findings include:
\begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{Spin–momentum locking}: the transverse spin of the guided mode is intrinsically tied to propagation direction, enabling nonreciprocal light–matter interactions.
    \item \textbf{Chirality parameter}: defined as $C = (\kappa_R - \kappa_L)/(\kappa_R + \kappa_L)$, with perfect chiral coupling reached at $C=1$ when $\kappa_L=0$.
    \item \textbf{Critical coupling condition}: perfect absorption occurs when $\kappa_R = 2\gamma_i$, yielding $\sim 100\%$ absorption in one direction while leaving the opposite direction transparent.
    \item \textbf{Extendibility}: integration of additional YIG spheres enabled \emph{bidirectional} and \emph{multiband} perfect absorption, illustrating the scalability of chiral informational networks.
\end{itemize}

\vspace{1em}

\noindent
These results strongly resonate with the Telascura framework:
\begin{itemize}
    \item The condition for \emph{perfect absorption} mirrors the Codex Alpha criterion $\nabla \mathcal{K} \rightarrow 1$, i.e. the achievement of \textbf{perfect informational coherence}.
    \item The observed \emph{nonreciprocity} corresponds to directional asymmetry consistent with the emergence of \textbf{retrocausal channels} in informational space.
    \item The scalability with multiple YIG spheres reflects the principle that informational coherence is a \textbf{network property}, extensible across nodes, as in Telascura’s multi-scale architecture.
\end{itemize}

\vspace{1em}

\noindent
Although the platform of Qian \emph{et al.} is confined to photonic–magnonic systems at GHz frequencies, it provides experimental validation of a central principle of Codex Alpha:  
\textbf{coherence, stability, and directionality emerge from topological constraints on informational networks}.  
This convergence strengthens the interpretation of $\nabla \mathcal{K}$ not merely as a theoretical construct but as a measurable condition across physical domains, from condensed matter to cosmology.

\begin{figure}[H]
  \centering
  \includegraphics[width=0.9\textwidth]{qian_codex_comparison.png}
  \caption{Conceptual comparison between the experimental validation of \textbf{unidirectional perfect absorption} in spin–momentum locked YIG–SSPP magnonic systems \cite{qian2025unidirectional} and the Codex Alpha prediction of \textbf{perfect informational coherence} ($\nabla \mathcal{K} \to 1$). 
  In both cases, stability and directionality emerge from \textbf{topological constraints on informational channels}, reinforcing the interpretation of coherence as a universal network property.}

\subsection*{Braided Magnetic Flux Ropes Across Scales}

A particularly relevant recent discovery concerns the identification of 
\emph{braided magnetic flux ropes} across a vast range of scales, from 
laboratory experiments to astrophysical structures \cite{zhang2025flux}. 
Bellan and Zhang demonstrated that such braided double-helix configurations 
naturally emerge as stable equilibria of magnetized plasmas, governed by 
a delicate balance of attractive and repulsive forces between parallel 
and anti-parallel current components. 

This result is significant for the Codex Alpha framework because it provides 
an independent validation of the universality of filamentary and helical 
structures across multiple orders of magnitude. The recognition that 
the same magnetohydrodynamic principles apply from centimeter-scale solar 
loop replicas in the laboratory to kiloparsec-scale astrophysical jets 
and nebular filaments strongly resonates with the Telascura paradigm 
developed in Chapter V. In that context, braided magnetic structures can 
be interpreted as physical manifestations of informational filaments and 
$\nabla \mathcal{K}$ coherence channels, stabilizing themselves through 
a topological balance analogous to the magnetic equilibrium described 
in plasma physics. 

\begin{figure}[H]
  \centering
  \includegraphics[width=0.95\textwidth]{braided-magnetic-flux.jpg}
  \caption{Four braided structures. (a) Astrophysical jet M-87, 3000 light years long; 
  (b) Double Helix Nebula, 70 light years long; (c) Solar prominence, 3000 kilometers long; 
  (d) Solar loop manufactured in Bellan lab at Caltech, 3 centimeters long. 
  Credit: (a) Passeto et al., Sophia Dagnello, NRAO/AUI/NSF; 
  (b) NASA/JPL-Caltech/M. Morris (UCLA); 
  (c) High Altitude Observatory Archives; 
  (d) Yang Zhang, Caltech Bellan Plasma Lab.}
  \label{fig:braided_flux}
\end{figure}

This discovery therefore provides an important link between the 
observational domain of plasma astrophysics and the theoretical 
informational structures proposed in the Codex Alpha 3.0, 
strengthening the interpretation of cosmic filaments as 
coherent informational braids. 

\subsection*{Universal Laws of Quantum Entanglement}

A recent breakthrough by Kusuki, Ooguri and Pal \cite{kusuki2025} has established 
universal laws governing quantum entanglement across conformal field theories (CFTs). 
Their results provide a rigorous foundation that connects the scaling of entanglement entropy 
with geometry, reinforcing and extending the framework already proposed in Codex Alpha 
(see Chapter V on emergent geometries of the Telascura).

The general definition of the Rényi entropy is:
\begin{equation}
S^{(n)}_A = \frac{1}{1-n} \log \text{Tr}\,\rho_A^n,
\end{equation}
where $\rho_A$ is the reduced density matrix for region $A$. 

In the universal $n \to 0$ limit, they obtain the scaling law:
\begin{equation}
S^{(n)}_A \sim \frac{f}{(2\pi n)^{d-1}} \,
\frac{\text{Area}(\partial A)}{(d-2)\,\epsilon^{d-2}}
+ O\!\left(\frac{1}{n^{d-2}}\right),
\end{equation}
with $f$ a universal constant related to the effective thermal action, and $\epsilon$ the 
short-distance cutoff. This structure echoes the role of the informational gradient 
$\nabla \mathcal{K}$ in Codex Alpha, which also scales with geometric and cutoff parameters.

In two dimensions, they derive the explicit formula:
\begin{equation}
S^{(n)}_A = \frac{c}{6}\left(\frac{1}{n}+1\right)
\log\frac{|A|}{2\epsilon} + s_a + s_b,
\end{equation}
where $c$ is the central charge and $s_a, s_b$ are boundary entropies. This result, 
sometimes called the ``hot spot formula'', can be interpreted within Codex Alpha as 
a manifestation of coherent informational attractors, regions where the 
informational field becomes dominated by extreme local conditions.

\begin{figure}[H]
  \centering
  \includegraphics[width=0.55\textwidth]{HIBERT.png}
  \caption{Regularization prescription in 2D CFT: by inserting a physical boundary of size 
  $2\epsilon$ at the entangling surface, the CFT Hilbert space decomposes. 
  Image adapted from \cite{kusuki2025}.}
\end{figure}

These universal entanglement laws directly support the Codex Alpha hypothesis of 
a fundamental informational principle: they demonstrate that entanglement 
obeys scalable, geometry-dependent laws across all energy scales. The results 
strengthen the connection between holographic principles in CFT and the 
informational cosmology of the Telascura, reinforcing the Codex Alpha framework 
as a viable path toward unification.

% ========= 18.X — Recent results on power spectra + squeezed bispectrum =========
\subsection*{Joint constraints from pre/post–reconstruction power spectra and the squeezed–limit bispectrum}
% Collegamento al Cap. 5 (metodi statistici e informazione non-lineare)
\noindent\textit{Context.} In Chapter~5 we discussed how higher–order statistics encode non-linear information that is only partially accessible with the standard galaxy power spectrum. A recent Communications Physics paper \cite{wang2024extracting} demonstrates that much of that information can be efficiently recovered by \emph{combining} three two–point statistics—(i) the pre–reconstruction power spectrum $P_{\rm pre}$, (ii) the post–reconstruction spectrum $P_{\rm post}$, and (iii) their cross spectrum $P_{\rm cross}$—and by comparing such a combination with the pre/post spectrum jointly with the \emph{squeezed–limit} bispectrum monopole $B^{\rm SL}_0$.

\paragraph{Measured monopoles and rotated combinations.}
Using the MOLINO galaxy mocks, the monopole $P_0$ of $P_{\rm pre}$, $P_{\rm post}$, and $P_{\rm cross}$ shows a rapid loss of coherence of $P_{\rm cross}$ on quasi–non–linear scales ($k\gtrsim 0.1\,h\,{\rm Mpc}^{-1}$), signalling decorrelation between $P_{\rm pre}$ and $P_{\rm post}$ due to reconstruction \cite{wang2024extracting}. From the original data vector $\{P_{\rm pre},P_{\rm post},P_{\rm cross}\}$ the authors define three \emph{rotated} linear combinations (their Eq.~(1)):
\begin{equation}
\label{eq:rotated}
P_{R\Delta} \equiv P_{\rm cross}-P_{\rm post},\qquad
P_{\Delta\Delta} \equiv P_{\rm pre}+P_{\rm post}-2\,P_{\rm cross},\qquad
P_{\delta\Delta} \equiv P_{\rm pre}-P_{\rm cross}.
\end{equation}
These combinations isolate integrated contributions from higher–order statistics: $P_{\Delta\Delta}$ is dominated by the (integrated) squeezed–limit bispectrum, while $P_{R\Delta}$ captures leading trispectrum (folded/squeezed) contributions \cite{wang2024extracting}. Operationally, they behave like “proxies” for $B$ and $T$ that can be measured with two–point estimators.

\paragraph{Cross–power estimator (noise–robust).}
To obtain an unbiased $P_{\rm cross}$ without explicit noise subtraction, the analysis employs the half–sum/half–difference (HS–HD) trick. After randomly splitting the catalogue into two halves $\delta_1,\delta_2$ (with reconstructed fields $R_1,R_2$), define
\begin{equation}
{\rm HS}\equiv\frac{\delta_1+\delta_2}{2},\quad
{\rm HD}\equiv\frac{\delta_1-\delta_2}{2},\qquad
{\rm HSR}\equiv\frac{R_1+R_2}{2},\quad
{\rm HDR}\equiv\frac{R_1-R_2}{2}.
\end{equation}
The cross–power estimator becomes (their Eqs.~(2)–(4))
\begin{equation}
\widehat P_{\rm cross}=\langle{\rm HS},{\rm HSR}\rangle-\langle{\rm HD},{\rm HDR}\rangle
=\frac{\langle\delta_1,R_2\rangle+\langle\delta_2,R_1\rangle}{2},
\end{equation}
whose scatter directly estimates the 4-point covariance entering Fig.~\ref{fig:matrix}.

\paragraph{Bispectrum monopole (squeezed–limit).}
The galaxy bispectrum monopole $B_0$ is measured (pySpectrum) as
\begin{equation}
\label{eq:B0}
B_0(k_1,k_2,k_3)=\frac{1}{V_B}\!\!\int_{k_1}\!\!d^3q_1\!\!\int_{k_2}\!\!d^3q_2\!\!\int_{k_3}\!\!d^3q_3\,
\delta_{\rm D}(\mathbf{q}_{123})\,\delta(\mathbf{q}_1)\delta(\mathbf{q}_2)\delta(\mathbf{q}_3)\;-\;B^{\rm SN}_0,
\end{equation}
and the analysis often focuses on the squeezed configuration $k_1=k_2\gg k_3$ ($B^{\rm SL}_0$), which is the piece most strongly correlated with $P_{\Delta\Delta}$.

\paragraph{AP distortions and multipoles.}
For BAO/RSD and Alcock–Paczynski tests, the first three even multipoles are used to reconstruct $P(k,\mu)$ and $B$,
\begin{equation}
P(k,\mu)\simeq\sum_{\ell=0,2,4}P_\ell(k)\,L_\ell(\mu),\qquad
B(k_1,k_2,k_3;\mu_1,\mu_2)\simeq\sum_{\ell=0,2,4}B_{\ell,m=0}(k_1,k_2,k_3)\,Y_{\ell,m=0},
\end{equation}
with the usual AP rescalings for $(k,\mu)\mapsto (q,\nu)$ and the corresponding integrals for $P_\ell$ and $B_0$ (their Eqs.~(10)–(14)). 

\paragraph{Fisher formalism and Figures of Merit.}
Cosmological and HOD parameters are projected with a Fisher analysis on the parameter set 
$\Theta=\{\Omega_m,\Omega_b,h,n_s,\sigma_8,M_\nu,\text{HOD}\}$.
The paper reports single–parameter FoMs and marginalised uncertainties using
\begin{equation}
X\equiv\sqrt{F_{ii}},\qquad Y\equiv\frac{1}{\sqrt{C_{ii}}}\quad(C\equiv F^{-1}),
\end{equation}
and compares the data vectors $P_{\rm all}\equiv\{P_{\rm pre},P_{\rm cross},P_{\rm post}\}$ and $P_{\rm pre}+B_0$ at $k_{\max}=\{0.2,0.5\}\,h\,{\rm Mpc}^{-1}$.

\paragraph{Main quantitative result (useful for Chapter~18).}
On quasi–linear scales $k_{\max}=0.2\,h\,{\rm Mpc}^{-1}$ the combined two–point data $P_{\rm all}$ yields a FoM larger than $P_{\rm pre}$ by a factor $\sim2.7$ and than $P_{\rm post}$ by $\sim1.7$, and even \emph{slightly} better than $P_{\rm post}+B_0$ (by $\sim13\%$). 
At $k_{\max}=0.5\,h\,{\rm Mpc}^{-1}$, $P_{\rm all}$ still outperforms $P_{\rm pre}$ and $P_{\rm post}$ (by factors $\sim2.1$ and $\sim1.5$) and essentially matches $P_{\rm pre}+B_0$, though trails $P_{\rm post}+B_0$ by $\sim10\%$.
Hence, a joint analysis of $\{P_{\rm pre},P_{\rm cross},P_{\rm post}\}$ can \emph{recover} nearly all the information one would otherwise obtain by adding the (computationally expensive) bispectrum \cite{wang2024extracting}.

\paragraph{Relevance for Codex Alpha 3.0.}
This outcome dovetails with our Chapter~5 discussion and the Codex–Alpha view that (i) non–linear information can be “projected” into effective two–point estimators via suitable transforms, and (ii) the squeezed–limit $B_0$ is the dominant higher–order piece that couples to long modes. The rotated combinations in Eq.~\eqref{eq:rotated} provide precisely the kind of compressed observables we advocate for Telascura–style informational pipelines.
